various names; in the 19th 
c. it was called Tower of the 
Janissaries or Blood Tower  
as it served as jail for 
prisoners on death row 
whose life was eventually 
taken by the Janissaries on 
the ramparts. In 1890 it was 
painted white thus acquiring 
its current name. A particularly 
interesting exhibition is held 
in the Tower on the history 
of Thessaloniki (see p. 73); 
from the top of the Tower 
you can enjoy the panoramic 
view. The small square around 
the monument is one of the 
hotspots in town; this is where 
small boat bars leave for a 
short run within the Thermaic 
Gulf, serving coffee or a drink. 
Opposite lies the Park of the 
White Tower where you will

a bar, a playground and

1.2  Royal [Vasiliko]

It was built in 1940, got

In the following centuries, the 
Turks completed reinforcement 
works in various places. The 
wall inscriptions describe the 
interventions and restorations 
that took place over time. The 
walls followed the shape of an 
irregular trapezium and ended 
to the west in Vardariou Tower 
(see p. 59) and to the east in 
the White Tower (see p. 24), 
reaching a total length of 7 km. 
After 1870, demolition of the 
seafront walls as well as of parts 
of the western and eastern walls 
began, in order to sanitise the 
plains and also to expand the 
city. Today there are 3 remaining 
km of city walls (mainly on Ano 
Poli, see p. 42); their height 
ranges from 8.30 to 10.50 m. 
and their width may measure 
up to 4.50 m, making them 
an impressive monument and 
one of great archaeological and 
cultural value.

inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects 
Thessaloniki with the rest of 
Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul; 
it is also the bus terminus 
towards most of the city areas. 
This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it is exclusively 
used as a cargo train station. 
This is where the German 
occupation forces mustered 
about 50,000 Jewish residents, 
from March until August 1943, 
in order to send them by train 
off to concentration camps.
2.3  Top Hane (Vardariou 
Tower).
Situated where the west 
and seafront city walls used 
to meet, this Tower was built 
by the Ottomans in 1546 and 
it was known as the Armoury 
Tower. It is a six-sided, three-
storey and 10-metre high tower 
which used to be the main city 
stronghold.']

reference_contexts: ['MUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a notable landmark with a rich history. It was built in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. The station is situated on Monastiriou Street, which is renamed Egnatia Street at some point. The station's construction was officially recognized in 1951, and it was inaugurated in 1962. The Railway Station is a symbol of Thessaloniki's connection to the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. The station is also a popular spot for locals and tourists alike, offering a glimpse into the city's history and culture. 

Some notable features of the Railway Station include its neoclassical architecture, its connection to Skopje, Belgrade, and Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul), and its significance in the Greek Army's history. The station's exterior side combines modern and classical elements, with wings added on the sides. It is also the bus terminus for most city areas and the location of the west metro line terminus under construction. 

Visitors to the Railway Station can expect to see a mix of old and new architecture, with the station's historic buildings standing alongside modern amenities. The station's location in the city centre makes it easily accessible, and its proximity to other landmarks and attractions makes it an ideal starting point for sightseeing excursions. Overall, the Railway Station is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the history and culture of Thessaloniki. Its unique blend of old and new architecture, combined with its rich history and cultural significance, make it a truly Instagrammable spot.
reference: The Railway Station in Thessaloniki, located on Monastiriou Street (which was renamed Egnatia Street), began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. Notable features include the old steam engine that is situated in front of the station and the Vardariou Tower, also known as Top Hane.

user_input: Can you tell me how to get to the central square from the seafront using I. Passalidis Street?
retrieved_contexts:
['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', '88
DAY EXCURSIONS
Jewish quarter in Europe, 
which maintains a traditional 
character in its entirety. It 
is worth taking a walk and 
visiting the Roman, Ottoman 
and Industrial age monuments 
in the traditional districts of 
Kyriotissa, Panagia Dexia, and 
Makariotissa; you can also visit 
the Public Central Library which 
has earned an international 
award, or relax in the parks  
and squares.
How to get there.  
Vergina is about 63 km SW  
of Thessaloniki. If you travel by 
car, follow the signs to Veroia 
and after that to Vergina. You 
can also take the intercity bus 
or the train to reach Veroia  
and then take the local bus  
to Vergina.
3 	DION
This most enchanting 
archaeological site is  
located under the imposing 
Olympus mountain range, in  
a 150-hectare green area amid 
flowing waters coming from 
Vafyras River and from other 
springs; it is the habitat of 
many species of birds, reptiles 
and amphibians. This used to 
be a sacred place to ancient 
Macedonians who worshipped 
Olympian Zeus and the Muses 
[daughters of Zeus] here.', 'In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans. There are 
swimming pools for men 
and women, 10 personal 
hydromassage areas where 
mineral spring water is used, 
saunas, a gym and areas 
for mud treatment. In the 
summer, visitors can enjoy 
a special mud therapy by 
the lake shore which gets 
usually dried up during the 
warmest season of the year. 
In the grounds you will find 
a physiotherapy centre and 
a medical clinic, a hotel, a 
restaurant, a bar, basketball 
and football fields.
How to get there. 
Pikrolimni is located 23 
km N of Thessaloniki. If 
you travel by car, follow the 
signs to Kilkis and after that, 
from Galliko village head 
for Xylokeratia (Pikrolimni). 
Alternatively there is a bus 
from Dimokratias square 
(Vardari) leaving daily at 9 am, 
which will take you to the Mud 
Therapy Centre for free.
DAY EXCURSIONS
114', 'The area was inhabited 
for the first time in 1923 
when refugees from Minor 
Asia settled here. Until then 
Peraia was the property of a 
Turkish Bey [a dignitary], Neoi 
Epivates was a Turkish estate 
(Bahçe Çiflik in Turkish) and 
Agia Triada was called White 
Fountain. Today, these areas 
have evolved into suburbs 
and seaside resorts. Along 
the entire waterfront you will 
find beaches, awarded the 
Blue Flag for beach quality, 
with facilities for water 
sports, beach volleyball and 
so on. There are fish tavernas, 
cafés and bars bordering 
the seafront pedestrian way, 
offering a fine seaview.
How to get there. You  
can take the buses Nos. 71 
and 71A for N. Michaniona 
from the Railway Station Stop 
in July and August (get off at  
any stop from Paralia Peraias  
to Agia Triada). Throughout  
the year, bus lines 02 and

any one of the 72, 72A, 72B  
74', '49
5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
The quarter was created mainly 
to provide housing for the 
refugees who settled there 
in the early 20th c.; however 
traces of settlements exist 
which date as far back as the 
2nd c. AD. In the lush greenery 
of the Municipal Grove there 
is a Municipal Theatre, where 
major cultural events are held 
during the summer months, 
and an open-air cinema. 
Further south, on a low hill, you 
will see the imposing church 
of Agioi Theodoroi, built on 
ruins of a 7th c. Byzantine 
church, where the view of the 
entire city is amazing. In the 
neighbouring Elpidos Street 
towards the city walls you will 
see a group of refugee houses 
– the area is in the process of 
being changed into a “Cultural 
Neighbourhood”.
How to get there: To 
reach Sykees, you can either 
walk from Ano Poli or take 
the bus no. 23 (terminus at 
Eleftherias sq.) and get off at 
Agios Charalampos stop.

response:
To get to the central square from the seafront using I. Passalidis Street, head north along I. Passalidis Street and then turn left onto Komninon Street. The central square is located on your right-hand side, and you can see the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. 

You can take the bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square and get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. Alternatively, you can walk from the seafront and follow the directions to I. Passalidis Street and then Komninon Street. 

The walk should take around 10-15 minutes. You will pass by various shops, cafes, and restaurants along the way. 

Keep in mind that the central square is a popular spot, especially during the summer months. You may encounter crowds and long lines, but it's definitely worth visiting. 

Make sure to take plenty of photos, as the central square is an Instagrammable spot! You'll have plenty of opportunities to capture the beautiful architecture and lively atmosphere. 

Overall, getting to the central square from the seafront using I. Passalidis Street is a great way to experience the heart of the city. Enjoy your visit!
reference: To reach the central square from the seafront via I. Passalidis Street, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A that leave from Eleftherias square. You should get off at either the Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at the Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area.

SQUARE
Thessaloniki’s central square 
is one of the largest and most 
impressive in Greece, and  
a bustling place twenty four 
hours a day. It is one of the 
few sections of the Hébrard 
Committee urban plan, which 
came to be realised after the 
1917 fire, although it became 
fully shaped in as late as the 
early 1960s. It is a square 
on the seafront, with a 100 
m. opening, that affords an 
amazing view of the Thermaic 
Gulf and the Olympus massif. 
The monumental style of 
architecture is shown in the 
buildings’ facades, colonnades, 
arcades and porticos, which 
combine elements from the 
city’s Byzantine tradition 
with European interwar 
period motifs.', '44
5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
6 	TSITSANI SQUARE
This small square with beautiful,  
well-tended houses is located 
in between Moni Vlatadon and 
Hosios David where you can go 
if you take Timotheou Street 
(notice the ottoman fountain) 
and Dimitriou Poliorkitou Street. 
In the square centre you will see 
the bust of V. Tsitsanis (1915 – 
1984) a leading Greek popular 
composer who lived and worked 
in the town during World War II.
7 	EPTAPYRGIOU STREET
This is one of the most 
interesting roads of Ano Poli 
quarter. It follows the interior 
line of the northern city walls 
which used to be the ramparts 
of the Acropolis (see also p. – 
for the city walls). It is worth 
taking a walk from the corner 
of Eptapyrgiou and Palamidiou 
Streets (to the west) where 
the 3rd Gate is - also known 
as “Eski Delik” – and head 
for the main Gate. Besides the 
interesting traditional buildings 
and the deserted Zihne Camii 
[Mosque] (1902) you will pass 
by the old refugee houses called 
“kastroplikta”; these were built 
along the line of the city walls or 
adjoining them – as far back as 
the early 1920’s. Similar houses 
can be seen also on the eastern 
and western walls.', '43
5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
2 	TSINARI
This area was named after 
the plane tree which was 
planted there in the early 20th 
c. (çınar is turkish for plane 
tree). You can reach it through 
Al. Papadopoulou Street, one 
of Ano Poli’s hallmark areas 
as are Tsamadou, Sachtouri 
and Isminis Streets. In Isminis 
Street you will find the House 
of Pontian Greeks. This is  
Ano Poli’s downtown spot 
and people who want to reach 
the neighbouring Sykies 
area go through here. In the 
centre, there is an ottoman 
fountain with a marble Roman 
sarcophagus; this is also 
where you will find the oldest 
restaurant in town (open since 
1885), a café and small shops.
3 	TERPSITHEA SQUARE
Take a good look at the 
remarkable listed buildings and 
the more recent ones as you 
walk along Pileos Street and 
head for Terpsithea Square. 
The buildings surrounding 
the square are amazing and 
offer a wonderful view of the 
town and the seafront; in the 
centre there is a playground 
and a small open-air theatre. 
Another impressive monument 
is the Tϋrbe (Tomb) of Musha  
Baba (1543), one of the late  
ottoman monuments  
of Thessaloniki, shaped  
as an octagon with decorative 
pointed frames on windows 
and a once lead-covered dome.']
reference_contexts: ['65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3']
response: To get to the central square from Eleftherias square, you can take bus line 5 or 5A from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. Then, follow the signs to the central square. The journey should take about 10-15 minutes, depending on traffic. You can also ask a local or a tourist information officer for directions. The central square is a great place to start your sightseeing, with many shops, cafes, and restaurants nearby. It's also a great spot to take some Instagrammable photos of the seafront and the surrounding buildings.
reference: You can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area to reach the central square.

response:
Naftikos Omilos is a popular area in Kalamaria, known for its vibrant atmosphere and entertainment options. It's a great spot to visit for a leisurely evening stroll or a night out with friends. The area is home to several clubs and venues that stay open until the early hours of the morning, making it a hub for socializing and meeting locals. During the summer months, many of these clubs and venues move to outdoor settings, offering a more relaxed atmosphere.

If you're looking for a taste of Thessaloniki's nightlife, Naftikos Omilos is definitely worth a visit. The area is easily accessible by public transportation, with several bus lines connecting it to other parts of the city. Visitors can also take a short taxi ride from the nearby Aretsou beach.

One of the unique features of Naftikos Omilos is its association with the Thessaloniki Marina. The marina is located nearby, and visitors can take a stroll along the waterfront, enjoying the sights and sounds of the marina and the bustling atmosphere of the area. The marina itself is a great spot for boat-watching and offers stunning views of the city.

If you're looking for a more Instagrammable spot, Naftikos Omilos has plenty to offer. The area is filled with colorful street art and lively murals, making it a photographer's paradise. Visitors can also capture stunning views of the Thessaloniki skyline from the rooftops of the nearby hotels and buildings.

Overall, Naftikos Omilos is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the best of Thessaloniki's nightlife and entertainment scene. Its vibrant atmosphere, stunning views, and Instagrammable spots make it a great spot to visit, whether you're looking for a night out or just want to soak up the local culture.
reference: Naftikos Omilos is a stop in the Aretsou area of Kalamaria, which is known for its local marine sports club located next to Aretsou-Krini beach. This area features a marina with a 242-berth capacity and offers power, water, and telephone services. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a popular spot throughout the year.

The Town Hall is located in the central square of Kalamaria, which is situated along Komninon Street, the main street of Kalamaria. It is easily accessible by public transportation, with bus lines 5 and 5A departing from Eleftherias square, and you can get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. You can find the Town Hall by walking along Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, and passing by shops, cafes, small bars, and restaurants. The Town Hall is also close to other notable landmarks such as the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, which is nearby and worth visiting. 

If you are interested in meeting locals, you can try visiting the nearby Aretsou-Krini beach, where you can enjoy the seafront and facilities of the local marine sports club. You can also try visiting the nearby Kalamaria Municipal Theatre, which is a great place to experience the local culture and meet locals. 

If you are looking for Instagrammable spots, you can try visiting the nearby Sofouli Street, which is a great place to take photos and enjoy the local atmosphere. 

Overall, the Town Hall is a great place to start your exploration of Kalamaria, and there are many other great places to visit in the area. 

Additional Information: 
The Town Hall is open to the public, and you can visit it during its regular hours of operation.

3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '82
Thessaloniki lies in the 
centre of a wide area that is 
extremely interesting from  
an archaeological, historical 
and natural point of view; 
there are countless options for 
outdoor activities, relaxing and 
entertainment. For instance, 
you can combine your stay 
in town with a day excursion 
to renowned archaeological 
sites and places of historical 
interest, to fascinating towns 
and great natural reserves  
or to areas offering recreation 
or relaxation.
1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.
MUST SEE:
Houses.']
reference_contexts: ['PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. Pontus is a historical region in modern-day Turkey, which played a significant role in the early history of Panorama, Thessaloniki. The text states that the first inhabitants of Panorama were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. This indicates that Pontus was an important source of migrants for the area. The mention of Pontus in relation to Panorama highlights the connection between the two regions and suggests that the early inhabitants of Panorama had ties to the region of Pontus. The text further reinforces this connection by noting that people from Pontus came to Thessaloniki, which implies that there was a significant exchange of people between the two regions. 

In terms of historical significance, Pontus is notable for being the region of origin for many of the early inhabitants of Panorama, Thessaloniki. This connection is a testament to the cultural and demographic exchange that occurred between the two regions. The fact that people from Pontus settled in Panorama and later in Thessaloniki suggests that there was a significant migration pattern that occurred in the region. This migration pattern had a lasting impact on the cultural and demographic makeup of the area. 

It's worth noting that the historical significance of Pontus extends beyond its connection to Panorama and Thessaloniki. Pontus has a rich and complex history, with its own distinct cultural and archaeological heritage. The region has been home to numerous civilizations and empires throughout history, including the ancient Greeks and Romans. The legacy of these civilizations can still be seen in the region's architecture, art, and cultural practices. 

Overall, the historical significance of Pontus is multifaceted and far-reaching. Its connection to the early inhabitants of Panorama and Thessaloniki is just one aspect of a larger cultural and historical narrative that encompasses the entire region.
reference: The first inhabitants of Panorama were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus, indicating the historical significance of Pontus in the region's early settlement.

['64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.

House] (Little Palace).', 'Greek revolts 
of that period in Macedonia are 
described in Room A; exhibits 
related to the Macedonian 
society of the late 19th c. are 
in Room B; a reconstruction 
of the office of the Greek 
General Consul is in Room C; 
the process of recruitment in 
the Greek guerilla forces of 
those times is on display in 
Room D; the role played by the 
clergy is depicted in Room E; 
the Balkan Wars are described 
in Room F; the course of 
Macedonian history following 
the Balkan Wars is in Room G. 
Costumes and authentic relics 
from the Balkan Wars Period 
(arms, uniforms among other 
items), are exhibited in the 
1st floor, as is a collection of 
miniature vehicles of the Greek 
army.
WAR MUSEUM
Exhibits include objects 
such as uniforms, arms, maps, 
battleship effigies, documents 
and military decorations, 
which are connected with the 
most significant events of the 
modern Greek history, from the 
1821 War of Independence 
until the 1944 liberation from 
the German Occupation forces. 
In the museum’s courtyard you 
will see armoured vehicles, 
fighters and torpedoes used by 
the Greek Army in the past.
ATATURK MUSEUM 
Exhibits occupy two floors: 
The 1st floor includes the 
parlour, the living room, the 
85 & 86.

building of

thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos). During 
the Byzantine and Ottoman 
period it was known as Sedes; 
in modern times, refugees 
inhabited the area in the early 
20th c.
MUST SEE:
Paramana Square.
In 2009 Thermi’s central 
square was awarded a prize 
for its futuristic design, in an 
architectural contest. The Town 
Hall and the two St. Nicholas 
churches (older and new one) 
are located here. This is where 
Karaoli-Dimitriou Street begins, 
the area’s business hub, where 
you will also find café-bars and 
restaurants.
Artificial lake.
Bordering on the suburb, 
the lake was created when 
a dam was built to contain 
the water running through 
a gully. It is the ideal place 
to make you feel refreshed 
and relaxed; in the summer 
the Dam Music Festival takes 
place there. Further north, 
within a short distance you 
will see the Environmental 
Park with a playground, tennis 
courts, basketball and football 
grounds.

Kalamaria holds significant historical importance due to its early inhabitants, who were primarily Greek refugees from the Caucasus, Minor Asia, and Pontus (modern-day northeast Turkey) during the 1920s. These refugees settled in Kalamaria and built their small houses, leaving a lasting legacy in the area. The city's modern-day identity is deeply rooted in this historical period, and the area remains a testament to the cultural heritage of these early settlers.

The influx of refugees in the 1920s had a profound impact on the development of Kalamaria, transforming it into the suburb we know today. The area's unique cultural blend, shaped by the experiences of its early inhabitants, is still palpable in its architecture, traditions, and community. Kalamaria's historical significance extends beyond its modern-day character, however, as it also played a crucial role in the city's growth and development during the early 20th century.

Today, visitors can still experience the essence of Kalamaria's early history by exploring its streets, buildings, and cultural landmarks. The area's many museums, historical sites, and cultural institutions offer a glimpse into the lives of the refugees who settled here, providing a deeper understanding of the city's complex history and the people who shaped it. By exploring Kalamaria's rich history, visitors can gain a deeper appreciation for the city's unique cultural identity and the resilience of its inhabitants. Overall, Kalamaria's historical significance is a testament to the enduring legacy of its early inhabitants and the profound impact they had on the city's development.
reference: Kalamaria was uninhabited until the early 20th century, although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located in the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus.

user_input: What is Mt Chortiatis?
retrieved_contexts:
['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', 'Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.
3 	PANORAMA
One of the best suburbs of 
Thessaloniki is situated at  
a 12 km distance S of the 
city centre and was built on 
the slope of Mt Chortiatis, 
offering a panoramic city view. 
It was uninhabited until the 
early 20th c., although traces 
of a prehistoric settlement 
have been located on the area. 
The first inhabitants were 
refugees from Asia Minor and 
Pontus. Today its largest part 
is covered by luxury villas and 
impressive detached homes; 
there is a small shopping 
area in the centre. Trigona 
Panoramatos [a cream puff 
pastry] – one of the city’s best 
known sweet delicacies – were 
created at a local confectionery 
in the 1950’s.
MUST SEE:
Platanakia.
It is a nice place for relaxing, 
in a wooded ravine, with a 
small Zoo and a café. A 6 km 
path begins here and leads 
up to the artificial lake (dam) 
of Thermi. Along the way you 
will come across spots for a 
brief rest, short waterfalls and 
fragments of eight Byzantine 
watermills.', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', 'The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos). During 
the Byzantine and Ottoman 
period it was known as Sedes; 
in modern times, refugees 
inhabited the area in the early 
20th c.
MUST SEE:
Paramana Square.
In 2009 Thermi’s central 
square was awarded a prize 
for its futuristic design, in an 
architectural contest. The Town 
Hall and the two St. Nicholas 
churches (older and new one) 
are located here. This is where 
Karaoli-Dimitriou Street begins, 
the area’s business hub, where 
you will also find café-bars and 
restaurants.
Artificial lake.
Bordering on the suburb, 
the lake was created when 
a dam was built to contain 
the water running through 
a gully. It is the ideal place 
to make you feel refreshed 
and relaxed; in the summer 
the Dam Music Festival takes 
place there. Further north, 
within a short distance you 
will see the Environmental 
Park with a playground, tennis 
courts, basketball and football 
grounds.
73.  
On the slopes of  
Mt. Chortiatis, 
towards Thermi.
74.  
Futuristic 
Paramana Sq. 
(Thermi).
73', '91
DAY EXCURSIONS
Praetorium and the public 
toilets (called Vespasians) 
which were located to the east.
The Hydraulis sector.
This was a complex of 
buildings named after the 
copper hydraulis [a type of pipe 
organ] found here along with 
a multitude of other copper 
items.
Villa of Dionysus.
This urban area house (2nd c.  
AD) is where an amazing mosaic  
was found, depicting Dionysus 
on a chariot coming out  
of the sea.
Archaeological Museum.
Housed in a brand new 
building, the Archaeological 
Museum showcases finds 
from the Dion area (statues, 
inscriptions, artefacts 
etc) classified in thematic 
groups (public buildings, 
houses, sanctuaries, ancient 
technology etc), and also finds 
from the foot of Mt Olympus 
and ancient Pydna. The Ancient 
Relics House lies opposite and 
showcases more recent finds 
from ongoing excavations.
3.1  Mt. Olympus.
The highest Greek mountain 
(2,918 m.) is globally known  
as the residence of the 12 gods 
of ancient Greek mythology. 
It is the first National Park of 
Greece (1938); in 1981 it was 
designated a World Biosphere 
Reserve area by UNESCO.']

Mt Chortiatis is a mountain located near the suburb of Chortiatis, which is situated on the outskirts of Thessaloniki. It is a popular destination for hiking, mountain biking, and off-roading. The mountain is covered with trees, including chestnut, oak, beech, and fir, and has a mountain refuge. There is also a path that begins from the Platanakia stop and leads up to the artificial lake of Thermi. The views from the top are panoramic, making it a great spot for sightseeing. The area is also home to the Vlatadon Monastery, which is mentioned in the text. The text mentions that the mountain is at an elevation of 1,201 meters. The location of Mt Chortiatis is suitable for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki, offering a chance to experience nature and enjoy the scenic views.

fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', 'The last part consists of 
what is believed to have 
been the tomb of Alexander 
IV, son of Alexander the 
Great and Roxanne, who was 
assassinated by Cassander in 
310 BC; a silver urn containing 
the bones of the dead person, 
framed with the ivory relief 
motifs of the funeral bed. 
In a separate room, visitors 
can watch a video where M. 
Andronikos takes them on a 
tour of the monuments. Other 
excavations in the wider area 
of the Aiges necropolis have 
unearthed archaic tombs, pit 
and cist tombs (6th and 5th c. 
BC), as well as temple-shaped 
macedonian tombs one of 
which apparently belonged  
to Queen Eurydice, the mother  
of King Philip II
Palace. It covers a 12,500 
m2 area and it used to be 
the largest and the most 
important construction (next 
to Parthenon, Athens) of the 
Hellenic Classical Antiquity. 
This two-storeyed edifice 
is presumed to be the work 
of Pytheos who was the 
architect of the Mausoleum 
of Halicarnassos [modern-day 
Bodrum, Turkey], one of the 7 
wonders of the ancient world. 
The palace’s architectural style 
is considered avant-garde for 
that time and it was built of 
limestone during the 2nd half 
of the 4th c. BC on a plateau; 
101, 102 & 
103.', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', 'Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.
3 	PANORAMA
One of the best suburbs of 
Thessaloniki is situated at  
a 12 km distance S of the 
city centre and was built on 
the slope of Mt Chortiatis, 
offering a panoramic city view. 
It was uninhabited until the 
early 20th c., although traces 
of a prehistoric settlement 
have been located on the area. 
The first inhabitants were 
refugees from Asia Minor and 
Pontus. Today its largest part 
is covered by luxury villas and 
impressive detached homes; 
there is a small shopping 
area in the centre. Trigona 
Panoramatos [a cream puff 
pastry] – one of the city’s best 
known sweet delicacies – were 
created at a local confectionery 
in the 1950’s.
MUST SEE:
Platanakia.
It is a nice place for relaxing, 
in a wooded ravine, with a 
small Zoo and a café. A 6 km 
path begins here and leads 
up to the artificial lake (dam) 
of Thermi. Along the way you 
will come across spots for a 
brief rest, short waterfalls and 
fragments of eight Byzantine 
watermills.', '101
and sports facilities.
Tour the suburban forests 
of Seich Sou (see p. 47) and 
Chortiatis (see p. 66) where 
you can follow the hiking trails 
or go mountain biking, find the 
spots designated for sports 
activities or just relax by the 
Deltas of Gallikos river and 
Axios-Loudias-Aliakmonas 
rivers (see p. 63) or by the 
lakes Koroneia and Volvi  
(see p. 93-94).
There are some quite 
interesting educational 
programmes for children, 
running in most museums 
(see p. 70 - 81), particularly 
in the Children’s Museum 
(see p. 79) which is the only one  
of its kind.
Have fun and at the same  
time get familiar with science  
and technology at the Noesis  
– Science Centre and 
Technology Museum (see p. 
67) or at the Nouvelle multi-
purpose venue (7th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Oraiokastro 
Road) where you can visit the 
Environmental Dinosaur Theme 
Park and see the natural size 
reconstructions of animals, 
the Mammoth Museum where 
fossils of the hairy mammoth 
are on display, the Cave where 
there are depictions of creation 
and prehistoric life in caves  
as well as the Interactive 
Museum of Greek Traditional 
Toys and Games  
(www.parkodeinosauron.gr).   
Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p.']

response:
Mt Chortiatis is a mountain located near Panorama, a suburb of Thessaloniki. It's a great place for hiking, mountain biking, and off-roading. You can follow the 32 charted paths, explore the mountain refuge, and enjoy the scenic views. There's also a mountain refuge (Kissos location) with a nice view. You can hike up to the top of the mountain and see the surrounding area. It's a great place to get some exercise and enjoy nature.

If you're interested in visiting Mt Chortiatis, I recommend taking the bus number 58 from Egnatia Street to Dimarchio, Astynomia, or Platanakia stop. The journey takes about 10 km NE of Panorama. You can also visit the nearby village of Vlatadon Monastery, which has a Byzantine aqueduct and offers a glimpse into the region's history.

Additionally, you can visit the nearby Panorama suburb, which offers a panoramic city view and a nice place to relax. There's also a nice place for relaxing, Platanakia, with a small Zoo and a café. You can take a 6 km path from Platanakia to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi, which offers beautiful views and a chance to rest.

Overall, Mt Chortiatis is a great place to explore nature and enjoy the scenic views. It's a bit of a hike, but the views are worth it. If you're looking for a more leisurely experience, you can always visit the nearby Panorama suburb or Platanakia.
reference: Mt Chortiatis is located near Panorama, a suburb of Thessaloniki, which is built on its slope. It offers a panoramic view of the city. The area has traces of prehistoric settlements and was first inhabited by refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus in the early 20th century. You can visit Platanakia, a nice place for relaxing with a small zoo and café, and a 6 km path that leads to the artificial lake of Thermi, featuring spots for rest, short waterfalls, and remnants of eight Byzantine watermills.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street in Thessaloniki has a significant historical presence, as it was officially opened in 1951 after construction began in 1939. This station marked a major improvement in Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure, connecting the city to the rest of Greece and beyond. The station's location on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, is a testament to the city's strategic importance as a hub for trade and commerce.

The Railway Station's historical significance extends beyond its operational status, as it played a crucial role in Thessaloniki's development as a major city in Greece. The station's construction and opening coincided with significant events in Thessaloniki's history, including the city's entry into the Greek War of Independence in 1912. The station's design and architecture reflect the city's rich cultural heritage, with elements of Byzantine and Ottoman influences evident in its construction.

The Railway Station's historical significance is also closely tied to Thessaloniki's transportation development. The station's location on the city's main thoroughfare, Egnatia Street, facilitated the movement of people and goods between the city and the wider region. The station's modernization in the 1950s marked a significant shift in Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure, enabling the city to connect more easily with the rest of Greece and beyond.

Today, the Railway Station remains an important landmark in Thessaloniki, offering a glimpse into the city's rich history and cultural heritage. Its historical significance continues to be celebrated by locals and visitors alike, making it a must-see destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's fascinating past.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. This station is a key part of Thessaloniki's transportation development, symbolizing the city's connectivity and progress in the mid-20th century. Additionally, the presence of the old steam engine in front of the station highlights the historical evolution of transportation in the area.

1 	EGNATIA STREET
This central avenue has 
been there practically since 
Thessaloniki’s founding,  
as it is a section of the road 
constructed by the Romans  
in the 2nd c. BC, and connected

1.1  Kolomvou Square.
The crossroads where

a bustling one! It was named 
after G. Colombo, an Italian 
who opened a hotel there  
in the early 20th century. This 
is the location of Kolomvou

of the avenue is lined with 
cafés and cosy little bars and 
the opposite wide pedestrian 
area next to the sea gets 
filled with strollers, cyclists, 
street artists and vendors. 
Among the modern blocks of 
flats, you will see some of the

Eleftherias square, the three-

to be; Aristotelous square;

the Interbellum (located

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a historically significant avenue in Thessaloniki, dating back to the Roman era when it was a major road connecting Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern-day Albania) with Constantinople. Today, it is a bustling shopping area lined with remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style, dating to the early 20th century.

Notable landmarks along Egnatia Street include the Dimokratia Square, the TIF grounds, the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, and the iconic White Tower. The avenue is also home to the famous Kolomvou Archway, which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars, and restaurants inside.

Visitors can walk along Egnatia Street to explore its rich history, visit museums, and take in the vibrant atmosphere. The street is particularly popular during the summer months, making it an ideal destination for leisure travelers.

As a solo traveler, you can easily find plenty of Instagrammable spots along Egnatia Street, from the stunning architecture to the lively street performers. With its rich history, cultural landmarks, and lively atmosphere, Egnatia Street is an unmissable destination for any traveler visiting Thessaloniki.

To make the most of your visit, consider visiting the Thessaloniki History Centre, located near the Ippodromiou square, to learn more about the city's fascinating history. Additionally, be sure to explore the nearby Agios Antonios church, a remarkable 18th-century church that offers a glimpse into the city's cultural heritage.

Overall, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination for any traveler looking to experience the best of Thessaloniki's history, culture, and leisure activities. Its rich significance, stunning landmarks, and vibrant atmosphere make it an unforgettable experience.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC to connect Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is unique for its peristyle and is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a significant historical landmark, playing a crucial role in the city's transportation and connection to the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. It was inaugurated in 1962 and serves as a bus terminus for most city areas, connecting Thessaloniki to the wider region. The station was built in 1894 in the neoclassical style and initially connected Thessaloniki with Skopje, Belgrade, Monastir, and Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul). Today, it is primarily used as a cargo train station, but its historical importance remains.

The Railway Station holds significance due to its connection to the German occupation forces during World War II. Between March and August 1943, approximately 50,000 Jewish residents were mustered at the station, awaiting transportation to concentration camps. This dark period in history is a poignant reminder of the atrocities committed during the war.

In addition to its historical significance, the Railway Station is also an important transportation hub, facilitating travel between Thessaloniki and surrounding cities. Its location on Monastiriou Street, now renamed Egnatia Street, makes it easily accessible from the city center.

Visitors can explore the station's exterior, which combines modern and classical elements, and its interior, which features a neoclassical design. The station's history and significance make it a must-see attraction for those interested in Thessaloniki's history and culture.

For solo travelers, the Railway Station offers a unique opportunity to learn about the city's past and its connection to the wider region. Its Instagrammable spots, such as the exterior and interior, make it an ideal location for capturing memorable photographs. Overall, the Railway Station is a must-visit attraction for anyone looking to experience Thessaloniki's history, culture, and transportation hub.
reference: The Railway Station in Thessaloniki, located on Monastiriou Street (renamed Egnatia Street), began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. It serves as a significant transportation hub in the city, symbolized by the old steam engine that fronts the station, reflecting its historical importance in facilitating travel and commerce.

Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance as it was built in 1894 and served as a major transportation hub connecting the city to Skopje, Belgrade, Monastir, and Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul). It was a crucial link between Greece and the rest of Europe, facilitating the movement of people, goods, and ideas. The station played a pivotal role in the city's development, especially during the 20th century, when it became a major stop for both domestic and international trains. Its neoclassical architecture, completed in 1951, is a testament to the city's rich cultural heritage. Today, the station is still used as a cargo train station, although its original function has largely been replaced by other transportation modes. Despite this, it remains an important part of Thessaloniki's history and a symbol of the city's connection to the wider world. 

In terms of its transportation role, the Railway Station has played a vital part in the city's growth and development. It has been a major gateway for tourists, allowing them to easily access various parts of the city. The station's proximity to other transportation hubs, such as the bus terminal and the metro line, makes it an ideal starting point for exploring Thessaloniki. Moreover, its historical significance has been preserved through the construction of the new metro line, which will terminate at the station. This will further enhance the station's role in the city's transportation network, making it a hub for both locals and tourists alike. 

Overall, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a significant historical landmark that continues to play an important role in the city's transportation network. Its neoclassical architecture and rich history make it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's cultural heritage.
reference: The Railway Station in Thessaloniki, located on Monastiriou Street (renamed Egnatia Street), began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. It serves as a significant transportation hub in the city, reflecting the development of railway infrastructure in the region.

for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.

Noesis –Science Centre 
and Technology Museum
It is the only one of its kind 
in Greece! Construction of 
this 14,000-m2 impressive, 
modern complex was 
completed in 2004 on a small 
hill affording a panoramic view 
of the area. It is considered 
as the modern successor of 
the Technology Museum of 
Thessaloniki. The premises 
include screening rooms, 
permanent exhibitions 
(Technology Museum), a 
conference centre, a digital 
library, spaces reserved for 
temporary exhibitions and

an amphitheatre for carrying

If you go by car, follow Ethnikis

6 	EPANOMI
This picturesque town 
(population: 7,500) is situated 
25 km SE of Thessaloniki. In 
the vicinity there are beautiful 
beaches, namely Ktima 
Karagiozi, Ormos, Palioura, 
Ageladariko, Mesimeri and 
Potamos; you will also see a 
half-sunken wreck of a small 
merchant vessel lying there 
since 1967. Tsairi (4 km S 
of Epanomi) is the location 
of a wetland, a refuge for 
over 80 species of birds. 
Gerovassiliou Wine Museum 
is situated 2 km N. and is the 
only one of its kind in northern 
Greece (for the museum see

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a significant historical landmark, built in 1939 and officially operational in 1951. It serves as a connection point for various destinations, including the Balkans, Greece, and Istanbul. This station has played a crucial role in the city's development, facilitating the movement of people and goods.

Located on Monastiriou Street, which is renamed Egnatia Street at some point, the Railway Station is situated in the heart of the city. It is part of a historic area that also features sections of the city's west walls, Byzantine and Ottoman monuments, and other archaeological sites. The station is notable for its old steam engine, which is still visible today.

The Railway Station has been used for various purposes over the years, including as a cargo train station and a hub for German occupation forces during World War II. In 1943, the station was the site where approximately 50,000 Jewish residents were gathered before being sent to concentration camps.

Today, the Railway Station is a popular tourist destination, offering a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich history and cultural heritage. Visitors can explore the surrounding area, which features a mix of modern and historical buildings, as well as the nearby Top Hane (Vardariou Tower), a six-sided, three-storey tower built by the Ottomans in 1546. The area is also home to the Temple of Aphrodite, a 6th-century BC archaeological site.

Overall, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is an important historical landmark that serves as a connection point for various destinations. Its location in the heart of the city, surrounded by historical and cultural attractions, makes it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's rich history and heritage.
reference: The Railway Station in Thessaloniki, located on Monastiriou Street (renamed Egnatia Street), has historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. Additionally, it features the Old steam engine fronting the station, which adds to its historical charm.

user_input: What cultural heritage does the UNESCO World Heritage site of Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represent?
retrieved_contexts:
['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', 'It was 
situated in the centre of 
the area which was called 
“Macedonian Land” by 
Herodotus [an ancient Greek 
Historian]. The first magnificent 
palaces of the Macedonian 
Kings were built here and 
the foundations of the great 
Macedon State were laid at 
that time. It was the sacred 
town of the Macedonians 
and remained so after the 
5th c. BC as Aiges was the 
place of origin of the Royal 
House of Argeades whose 
members were thought to be 
descendants of the House 
of Timenides and Hercules. 
In 168 BC the town was 
destroyed by the Romans and 
finally got deserted in the 1st 
c. AD. On the grounds of its 
importance, the archaeological 
site has been included in the 
UNESCO World Heritage List 
as a Multiple Thematic Focus 
Museum.
MUST SEE:
Royal Tombs. In 1977, 
the archaeologist Manolis 
Andronikos unearthed the 
royal tombs inside a big earth 
mound (Megali Toumpa - 
Great Tumulus). The tombs 
and the mound interior have 
been restructured into an 
amazing museum where the 
99
100', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.', '11
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
portal to the southwest and 
the cistern to the northwest. 
It is a complex tetrastyle 
cross-in-square church with 
a narthex and a peristyle on 
the three sides and extremely 
symmetrical proportions. 
When it was converted into 
a mosque, during the Turkish 
rule, the murals and mosaics – 
outstanding specimens  
of Palaeologan art dating  
to the 14th c. – were covered  
by plaster and a minaret was 
added to the southwestern side.
2 	
\x07PANAGIA CHALKEON 
CHURCH
It is located on the SW side 
of Dikastirion Sq. [Law Courts 
Sq.]. It was built in 1128 on 
the site of an ancient temple 
of Hephaestus or Kaveiros.  
It is a representative specimen 
of the architecture of the 
“School of Constantinople” and 
was thus named because of 
the area it was built on, known 
as the district of coppersmiths 
(masters of copper – chalkos). 
The most prominent feature 
is the level above the narthex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary).', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.']

response:
The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represent a unique and exceptional cultural heritage. These monuments, which include the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, the Panagia Chalkonos Church, and the Acheroopoitos Church, are outstanding specimens of Byzantine church-building and art. They are a testament to the rich cultural and historical heritage of the city, and their preservation is a significant contribution to the UNESCO World Heritage List.

The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki date back to the 4th to 15th centuries and showcase the city's status as a major center of the Byzantine Empire. The churches, which feature impressive mosaics, frescoes, and architectural designs, demonstrate the artistic and cultural achievements of the Byzantine period.

These monuments have been recognized as a cultural heritage site by UNESCO, which has acknowledged their significance in the history of Byzantine art and architecture. The preservation of these monuments is essential to understanding and appreciating the cultural and historical significance of Thessaloniki.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can experience the cultural heritage of the Byzantine monuments firsthand by exploring these churches and learning about their history and significance. The monuments offer a glimpse into the city's rich cultural past and provide a unique and unforgettable experience for visitors.

Overall, the Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represent a significant cultural heritage that is worth preserving and appreciating. They offer a unique and fascinating glimpse into the city's rich cultural past, and their preservation is essential to understanding and appreciating the cultural and historical significance of Thessaloniki.
reference: The UNESCO World Heritage site of Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represents a significant aspect of cultural heritage, showcasing early-Christian and Byzantine monuments that were constructed during the Byzantine period (4th – 15th century). These monuments reflect the city's historical importance as a center of Christianity and its architectural achievements, influencing the entire Byzantine world.

in Greece! Construction of

The station has been a major transportation hub in Thessaloniki, connecting the west and northwest suburbs with the city center. Over the years, the station has been renovated and expanded to accommodate the growing needs of the city's transportation infrastructure. Today, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street remains an essential part of Thessaloniki's transportation network, providing domestic and international train services.

The station's history is deeply intertwined with the city's development and growth. As Thessaloniki expanded and became a major urban center, the need for a modern and efficient transportation system became increasingly important. The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street played a crucial role in connecting the city to the surrounding suburbs and regional areas, facilitating the movement of people and goods.

In terms of transportation in Thessaloniki, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a critical link between the city center and the surrounding suburbs. It provides an efficient and reliable way to travel within the city and to regional areas, making it an essential stop for both locals and tourists. The station's proximity to other transportation hubs, such as the bus station and the port, also makes it a convenient starting point for exploring the city and its surroundings.

As a solo traveler, you can easily access the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street using public transportation, and from there, you can explore the city and its surroundings. The station's modern facilities and amenities, such as the updated charge rates for taxis, also make it an ideal starting point for your weekend getaway. Whether you're looking to explore the city's historic sites, visit the nearby suburbs, or simply enjoy the city's atmosphere, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is an excellent place to start your journey.

WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects

Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul;

This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it is exclusively 
used as a cargo train station. 
This is where the German 
occupation forces mustered 
about 50,000 Jewish residents, 
from March until August 1943, 
in order to send them by train 
off to concentration camps.
2.3  Top Hane (Vardariou 
Tower).
Situated where the west 
and seafront city walls used 
to meet, this Tower was built 
by the Ottomans in 1546 and 
it was known as the Armoury

storey and 10-metre high tower 
which used to be the main city

flats facing the adjacent

reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:', '<2-hop>

response:
Egnatia Street has significant historical importance in Thessaloniki, as it was the site where the Railway Station Stop, previously known as Monastiriou Street, was located. The Railway Station was built in 1939 and became operational in 1951, connecting Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. 

Historically, the Railway Station was a hub for the city, and its location on Egnatia Street is a testament to its importance. The street itself was also the site of the famous Top Hane (Vardariou Tower), which was built by the Ottomans in 1546 and served as the main city stronghold. Today, Egnatia Street is still a hub of activity, with the Railway Station Stop being a major transportation hub.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can explore the history of the Railway Station and the significance of Egnatia Street by visiting the Railway Station Stop and learning about the street's connection to the Top Hane. The street is also home to several historical landmarks, including the Arched Hall and the Theatre-stadium in Apellou Street, which offer a glimpse into the city's rich cultural heritage.

For solo travelers like yourself, Egnatia Street offers a wealth of historical and cultural experiences, making it an ideal destination for sightseers. With its rich history and cultural significance, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's past. Whether you're looking for Instagrammable spots or a chance to interact with locals, Egnatia Street has something for everyone.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC to connect Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. It is a bustling shopping area featuring important monuments and eclectic architecture. The Railway Station, located on Monastiriou Street, was renamed Egnatia Street at some point. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951, highlighting the historical evolution of the area as a transportation hub.

response:
Egnatia Street is a historic avenue in Thessaloniki that has been there since the city's founding days. It connects the city with Constantinople and was a significant stopover for East-West trading. Today, it's a bustling shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style, mostly old hotels that are worth observing.

Important places in Thessaloniki that can be found on Egnatia Street include:

* Kolomvou Square, a crossroads with Antigonidon Street that's now a leisure hub with cafés, bars, and restaurants inside.
* Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II.
* Bit-Pazar, a place where second-hand and antique dealers' shops are to be found.
* The White Tower, a historic tower that's now a museum.
* The Hirsch Building Mall and Plateia Mall, modern commercial centres that offer stylish clothing boutiques, department stores, and decoration shops.
* The traditional market west of Aristotelous Street and south of Egnatia Street, which is dotted with small shops, malls, and arcades.
* Modiano Market, a glass-roofed rectangular edifice containing 140 food shops inside its three arcades.

Egnatia Street is perfect for a solo traveler like you, as it offers a mix of shopping, dining, and historical experiences. You can easily navigate the street on foot, and there are plenty of cafes and restaurants to rest and recharge. With its rich history and vibrant atmosphere, Egnatia Street is an Instagrammable spot that's sure to make your Thessaloniki trip unforgettable.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Important places along Egnatia Street include Kolomvou Square, known for its bustling atmosphere and leisure spots, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its unique peristyle and ongoing renovation works.
