of residents occupies the 
area. Built in the early 20th c. 
as a private residence, the 
neighbouring Zardinidi Villa 
(or Morpourgo) houses the 
School of Music Studies, the 
Conservatoire of Northern 
Greece and an open air bar
2.4  Sofouli Street.
This main road connects 
the eastern districts of the 
Municipality of Thessaloniki with 
the district of Kalamaria (see 
p. 64). Along most of the way 
it is lined with trees in front of 
shops, cafés and restaurants 
– a hotspot for the locals; the 
seafront section of the road 
affords a lovely view of the 
city and you will also find cozy 
little bars and ouzo tavernas 
there. Between Logothetou 
and Rossidi Streets notice the 
complex of four detached houses 
with a garden, which bear a 
direct reference to that area’s 
past countryside atmosphere.
3 	\x07VASILISSIS OLGAS 
AVENUE
It used to be called the 
Countryside [Exochon] avenue or 
the Villas [Pyrgon] avenue and it 
was a favourite promenade area 
for the Thessalonians as it was 
built along the waterfront amid 
green surroundings. Nowadays, 
59', '30
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
flats facing the adjacent 
Ippodromiou square. This was 
a 450 m. long and a 95 m. 
wide structure and it used to 
be the centre of social activity 
for citizens until 390 AD, 
when emperor Theodosius 
ordered the massacre of 
7,000 Thessalonians there; 
the event led to the close-
down of the Hippodrome. It is 
worth visiting the Thessaloniki 
History Centre, situated in the 
square’s south side as well as 
the remarkable 18th c. Agios 
Antonios church in Margariti 
street nearby. 
8.7  Arched Hall.
It lies at the intersection  
of Gounari and Svolou streets. 
This was a place with heating 
installations for holding 
symposia and ceremonies. 
It had a direct access to 
the imperial box in the 
Hippodrome.
8.8  Theatre - stadium  
in Apellou Street.
The remains of a building 
have been located at 5 & 
7 Apellou St., and they are 
considered to have been part 
of the theatre-stadium of the 
town, which was in use from 
the 1st until the 4th c. AD.  
There are references connecting 
this place with the martyrdom 
of Agios Dimitrios, the city’s 
patron saint.
9 	THREE CHURCHES
On the south side of Egnatia 
Street, between K. Palaiologou 
St.']
reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a significant historical landmark in Thessaloniki, as it has been a central avenue since the city's founding, dating back to the Roman era. The street was constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, connecting the city with Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania). It has remained a vital thoroughfare for centuries, passing through various historical periods.

Notable landmarks along Egnatia Street include:

1. **Dimokratia Square**: The starting point of the avenue, which marks the beginning of the historic center.
2. **Thessaloniki Film Festival**: Located at the end of the street, near the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki.
3. **Electra Palace hotel**: A notable building on the west side of the street, built in the late 1960s.
4. **Olympion**: A concave building on the east side of the street, completed in the late 1950s, now serving as the seat of the Thessaloniki Film Festival.
5. **Kolomvou Archway**: A leisure hub located at the crossroads of Egnatia Street and Antigonidon Street.
6. **Hamza Bey Mosque**: A historic mosque built in 1467, showcasing the city's Ottoman heritage.
7. **Tyroloi Mansion**: A 20th-century mansion, now home to the School of Music Studies, Conservatoire of Northern Greece, and an open-air bar.

Egnatia Street is a treasure trove of Thessaloniki's history, offering a glimpse into the city's rich cultural and architectural heritage. Visitors can stroll along the avenue, taking in the sights and sounds of this iconic street, which has been a cornerstone of the city for centuries. With its array of historical landmarks, Egnatia Street is an unmissable destination for anyone visiting Thessaloniki.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds from metro excavations.

user_input: What are the main attractions and facilities in Kalamaria, and how does it compare to the suburb of Panorama in Thessaloniki?

['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', '66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '\x07Thessaloniki International Trade Fair (HELEXPO)
	71.	\x07Society for Macedonian Studies –  
National Theatre of Northern Greece	
	72.	Garden Theatre	
	73.	Royal Theatre

	75.	Vafopouleio Cultural Centre – Library	
	76.	Kalamaria Municipal Theatre

		SPORTS FACILITIES
	79.	Indoor Sports Hall (Byzantine Sports Club)	
	80.	\x07Alexandreio Sports Arena (Palais des Sports)
	81.	Kaftanzogleio stadium	
	82.	The National Swimming Pool	
	83.	Poseidonio Sports Centre	
	84.	Toumpa Football ground	
	85.	“Kleanthis Vikelidis” Football ground	
	86.	Kalamaria Football ground	
	87.	Nautical Club of Thessaloniki	
	88.	Water Sports Club of Kalamaria	
		PUBLIC TRANSPORT
	89.	Long Distance Bus Station	
	90.	New Railway Station	
	91.	Main Port	
		TRADITIONAL MARKETS
	92.	Kapani (Vlali Marketplace)

SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).']

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria and Panorama are two popular suburbs in Thessaloniki, each offering unique experiences. 

Kalamaria is known for its waterfront, green spaces, and self-contained shopping centre. The suburb is a great place to visit for those seeking a relaxed atmosphere. 

The main attractions in Kalamaria include:
- Sofouli Street, a charming street lined with shops and cafes.
- Kyverneio [Government House], a historic building that now serves as a museum.
- The waterfront, where visitors can enjoy the sea views and take a stroll.

Kalamaria is also home to various sports facilities, including the Indoor Sports Hall, Alexandreio Sports Arena, and Nautical Club of Thessaloniki.

In contrast, Panorama is a more laid-back and natural suburb, located on a hill overlooking the city. It offers stunning views of the city and surrounding landscape. 

The main attractions in Panorama include:
- The scenic views from the hilltop location.
- The Vrasna and Ano Stavros villages, which offer a glimpse into traditional Macedonian architecture.
- The nearby Lake Koroneia and Lake Volvi, perfect for hiking and outdoor activities.

While both suburbs offer unique experiences, Kalamaria is more vibrant and bustling, with a greater variety of amenities and activities. Panorama, on the other hand, is more relaxed and natural, with a focus on scenic views and outdoor activities.

Ultimately, the choice between Kalamaria and Panorama depends on your personal preferences. If you're looking for a more urban experience with plenty of amenities, Kalamaria may be the better choice. However, if you prefer a more laid-back and natural atmosphere, Panorama is definitely worth visiting. 

As a solo traveler, you may find Kalamaria's waterfront and shopping centre to be particularly appealing. The suburb's many sports facilities also make it an excellent choice for those looking for a more active holiday. 

On the other hand, Panorama's scenic views and outdoor activities may appeal more to those who enjoy nature and the great outdoors. 

Regardless of your choice, both suburbs offer a wealth of experiences and attractions that are sure to make your Thessaloniki holiday unforgettable.
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. In contrast, Panorama, situated 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It is known for its natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way.

the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police

This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64

tombs; a Neolithic settlement

with a cemetery dating to the

This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping

recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee

built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern-

despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee

a flavour of times goneby.

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a seaside suburb of Thessaloniki with a long waterfront, green spaces, and a self-contained shopping center. Its main street, Komninon Street, is pedestrian-only, lined with shops, cafes, and restaurants. The area is known for its refugee houses, which still maintain a flavor of the past. Kalamaria is also home to the Church of the Transfiguration of Christ and the Marine Sports Club.

In comparison, Panorama is a small suburb located northeast of Thessaloniki, situated on Mount Chortiatis. It offers breathtaking views, a mountain refuge, and 32 charted hiking paths. The suburb is known for its Byzantine aqueduct and ancient tombs. Panorama is a more secluded and natural area, with a strong focus on outdoor activities like hiking and biking.

While both suburbs offer unique experiences, Kalamaria's waterfront and shopping center provide a more urban atmosphere. Panorama, on the other hand, is ideal for those seeking a more peaceful and natural environment. If you're looking for a leisurely weekend getaway, Kalamaria's amenities might be more appealing. However, if you prefer a more relaxed, outdoor-focused experience, Panorama could be the better choice.

For Instagrammable spots, Kalamaria's waterfront and Komninon Street offer plenty of opportunities. Panorama's scenic views and ancient structures, such as the Byzantine aqueduct, would make for great photographs. Both suburbs have a strong sense of local culture, with Kalamaria's refugee houses and Panorama's natural beauty providing a glimpse into the region's history and heritage.

Overall, both Kalamaria and Panorama offer distinct attractions and features. While Kalamaria provides a more urban experience, Panorama offers a more natural and secluded environment. As a solo traveler, you might prefer Kalamaria's amenities, but if you're looking for a more relaxed experience, Panorama could be the better choice.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its popular areas along the seafront, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant spot year-round. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. While Kalamaria is bustling with seaside activities, Panorama provides a more tranquil environment with natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café.

2.4  Aretsou – Krini.

3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE

times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.

further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre

response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb of Thessaloniki known for its waterfront, green spaces, and self-contained shopping centre. The main attractions in Kalamaria include Sofouli Street, Kyverneio [Government House], and Aretsou-Krini beach, which features a marine sports and beach volleyball facility. The area is also home to the Kalamaria Municipal Theatre and the Toumpa Football ground.

Panorama, on the other hand, is a suburb located northeast of Thessaloniki, known for its mountainous terrain and scenic views. The main attractions in Panorama include the Vrasna and Ano Stavros villages, which offer traditional architecture and stunning views of Mt Kerdylia. The area is also home to the Lagkadas bus station and the Kilkis regional unit.

Compared to Panorama, Kalamaria is more densely populated and has a more urban feel. While Panorama offers a more rural experience with its mountainous terrain, Kalamaria provides a more accessible and convenient location, with its waterfront and shopping centre. Both areas offer unique attractions and experiences, but they cater to different tastes and preferences.

For a solo traveler looking for Instagrammable spots, Kalamaria's waterfront and Aretsou-Krini beach may be more appealing. However, for those seeking a more immersive cultural experience, Panorama's traditional villages and scenic views may be more rewarding.

In terms of accessibility, Kalamaria is more convenient, with its proximity to the city centre and main transportation hubs. Panorama, on the other hand, requires a longer journey from Thessaloniki, but its scenic views and rural atmosphere make it a worthwhile destination for those seeking a more relaxed pace.

Overall, both Kalamaria and Panorama offer unique attractions and experiences, making them valuable destinations for any traveler visiting Thessaloniki.
reference: Kalamaria features popular areas such as Aretsou and Krini, which stretch along the seafront and include a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, while Komninon Street, the town's main pedestrian street, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki's city center, offers a panoramic view from the slope of Mt Chortiatis and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It is known for its natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way.

['110
Thessaloniki State 
Symphony Orchestra 
(T.S.S.O.). 
It was established in 1959 
as the Symphony Orchestra 
of Northern Greece; in 1969 
it acquired its present name 
and was brought under state 
control. It is considered as one 
of the best of its kind in Greece 
and its musicians (approx. 100) 
have performed in some of the 
best known Festivals and music 
stages in Greece and abroad. 
Concerts take place in the 
Thessaloniki Concert Hall. 
Information: 73, Nikis Ave.
tel.: 2310 257.900
website: www.tsso.gr
Summer (open-air) cinemas. 
This is yet another attraction 
for visitors. Screenings take 
place in gardens, and you can 
watch a film while sipping your 
drink or having a snack, against 
a backdrop of trees and flowers. 
Films are not dubbed; Greek 
subtitles are used instead.
SPORTS 
Thessaloniki has a long 
tradition in sports. In recent 
decades, major sports events 
have taken place in the city 
(finals of european football and 
basketball games, international 
track and  field events, a 
marathon race, the 2004 
Olympic Games, international 
beach volleyball tournaments 
etc). A variety of modern and 
well equipped facilities are open 
to those who wish to practice 
their favourite sport or relax 
during their stay in town. Here 
is a list of sports facilities:

off, Peraia (see p. 67).   
Apart from the

a host of artistic events 
get organised in the city 
throughout the entire

(see p. 25), the Theatre of

the Forest Theatre [Theatro

Finally, the Thessaloniki

The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. response:
Kalamaria is a popular area in Thessaloniki, offering a range of attractions and facilities that can enhance a traveler's experience. Some notable spots include the Aretsou-Krini beach, which is perfect for relaxation and leisure activities. The waterfront area along N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, providing a great place to socialize and enjoy local cuisine. 

The Aretsou-Krini open-air cinema is another excellent option for those looking for entertainment, and the local marine sports club is a great place to meet locals and engage in water activities. The Kalamaria Municipal Theatre is also worth visiting, offering a range of cultural events and performances.

For sports enthusiasts, the Poseidonio Sports Centre is a great facility, featuring two swimming pools, basketball, tennis, volleyball, and handball fields. The Kaftanzogleio National Stadium is another excellent option for sports fans, hosting various events and activities.

For Instagrammable spots, the waterfront area along N. Plastira Street is a must-visit, offering stunning views of the sea and surrounding landscape. The Aretsou-Krini beach is also a great spot for capturing memorable photos.

Overall, Kalamaria offers a range of attractions and facilities that cater to different interests and preferences. Whether you're looking for relaxation, entertainment, sports, or cultural events, Kalamaria has something for everyone. With its laid-back atmosphere and stunning natural beauty, Kalamaria is an excellent choice for a leisurely weekend getaway in Thessaloniki.
reference: In Kalamaria, travelers can enjoy the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and offers shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located.

['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.

SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are.

area via I. Passalidis Street.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its beautiful beaches, green spaces, and self-contained shopping centre. It's an ideal place for leisure activities, with many cafes, bars, and restaurants along the waterfront, N. Plastira Street, and Komninon Street. The area is also home to the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, making it a great spot for those who seek familiar experiences.

In comparison, Panorama is a small suburb located near Mt Chortiatis, offering stunning views of the surrounding landscape. It's an ideal destination for hikers and mountain bikers, with 32 charted paths and a mountain refuge. The area is also home to a Byzantine aqueduct, which dates back to the Roman times. While Kalamaria is more urban and lively, Panorama is more peaceful and serene, offering a chance to disconnect from the city.

Both suburbs have unique attractions, but they cater to different tastes. Kalamaria is perfect for those who enjoy the city's amenities and activities, while Panorama is ideal for nature lovers and those seeking a more tranquil experience. If you're looking for Instagrammable spots, Kalamaria's waterfront and cafes might be more appealing, but if you prefer to immerse yourself in nature, Panorama is the better choice.

In terms of accessibility, both suburbs are easily reached by public transportation, making them convenient for solo travelers. However, Kalamaria's central square and shops might be more appealing to those with an interest in local culture and meeting locals.

Overall, both Kalamaria and Panorama offer a unique experience, and the choice between them ultimately depends on your personal preferences. If you're looking for a lively, urban atmosphere, Kalamaria might be the better choice, but if you prefer a more peaceful and natural setting, Panorama is the way to go.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its popular areas along the seafront, such as Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant area year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines 5 and 5A. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It has historical significance, being settled by refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus in the early 20th century. A notable attraction in Panorama is Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, along with a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake, showcasing natural beauty and historical remnants like Byzantine watermills.

Situated on cape Mikro

Little Palace was built in the

['<1-hop>

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a significant suburb of Thessaloniki that offers a unique blend of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and modern amenities. Some notable features and attractions that enhance its appeal as a travel destination include:

*   The waterfront promenade, which offers stunning views of the Aegean Sea and the surrounding landscape.
*   The historic refugee houses, which provide a glimpse into the area's rich cultural heritage and the experiences of the Greek refugee populations that settled here in the 1920s.
*   The modern shopping centre, which offers a range of amenities and services for visitors.
*   The nearby White Tower, which is a must-visit attraction for anyone interested in history and culture.
*   The scenic views of the surrounding countryside, which can be enjoyed from various vantage points throughout the area.
*   The vibrant atmosphere of the area, which is characterized by a mix of traditional and modern architecture, and a lively arts and culture scene.
*   The convenient access to the city centre, which makes it easy for visitors to explore other areas of Thessaloniki and experience the city's many attractions.

Overall, Kalamaria offers a unique and compelling travel destination that is sure to appeal to visitors looking for a mix of natural beauty, cultural heritage, and modern amenities. Its proximity to the city centre, scenic views, and vibrant atmosphere make it an attractive option for those seeking a leisurely weekend getaway or a longer stay in Thessaloniki. Whether you're interested in history, culture, or simply enjoying the local cuisine and atmosphere, Kalamaria has something to offer.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square, making it easy for travelers to explore these attractions.

retrieved_contexts:
['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', 'In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans. There are 
swimming pools for men 
and women, 10 personal 
hydromassage areas where 
mineral spring water is used, 
saunas, a gym and areas 
for mud treatment. In the 
summer, visitors can enjoy 
a special mud therapy by 
the lake shore which gets 
usually dried up during the 
warmest season of the year. 
In the grounds you will find 
a physiotherapy centre and 
a medical clinic, a hotel, a 
restaurant, a bar, basketball 
and football fields.
How to get there. 
Pikrolimni is located 23 
km N of Thessaloniki. If 
you travel by car, follow the 
signs to Kilkis and after that, 
from Galliko village head 
for Xylokeratia (Pikrolimni). 
Alternatively there is a bus 
from Dimokratias square 
(Vardari) leaving daily at 9 am, 
which will take you to the Mud 
Therapy Centre for free.
DAY EXCURSIONS
114', 'The area was inhabited 
for the first time in 1923 
when refugees from Minor 
Asia settled here. Until then 
Peraia was the property of a 
Turkish Bey [a dignitary], Neoi 
Epivates was a Turkish estate 
(Bahçe Çiflik in Turkish) and 
Agia Triada was called White 
Fountain. Today, these areas 
have evolved into suburbs 
and seaside resorts. Along 
the entire waterfront you will 
find beaches, awarded the 
Blue Flag for beach quality, 
with facilities for water 
sports, beach volleyball and 
so on. There are fish tavernas, 
cafés and bars bordering 
the seafront pedestrian way, 
offering a fine seaview.
How to get there. You  
can take the buses Nos. 71 
and 71A for N. Michaniona 
from the Railway Station Stop 
in July and August (get off at  
any stop from Paralia Peraias  
to Agia Triada). Throughout  
the year, bus lines 02 and  
02A will get you to A.S. IKEA  
station where you can board  
any one of the 72, 72A, 72B  
74', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '98
NIGHTLIFE
facilities. During the summer 
months though, most of 
those clubs and venues move 
to open-air grounds in the 
airport area (see p. 106). 
Another favourite area to 
Thessalonians is Kalamaria 
(see p. 64) and, a bit further 
off, Peraia (see p. 67).   
Apart from the 
entertainment options, 
a host of artistic events 
get organised in the city 
throughout the entire 
year: choose among the 
Thessaloniki Concert Hall 
[Megaro] (see p. 52), the 
Vasiliko [Royal] Theatre  
(see p. 25), the Theatre of 
the Society for Macedonian 
Studies (see p. 25 & 109), 
Moni Lazariston (see p. 61),  
the Forest Theatre [Theatro 
Dasous] and the Theatre  
of the Earth [Theatro Gis] 
(see p. 48); or you can opt for a 
visit to museums (see p. 70-81) 
and smaller cultural venues. Last 
but not least, you can visit the 
International Film Festival, 
the Thessaloniki Book Fair, the 
Demetria Festival (see p. 108-
109), and other venues housing 
events on a smaller scale by  
private companies or city 
agencies.
Finally, the Thessaloniki 
Regency Casino is located 
at the 12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road 
and is open around the clock.']

The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a popular area in Thessaloniki, known for its beaches, nightlife, and shopping. Two of the most popular areas in Kalamaria are Aretsou-Krini and Komninon Street. 

To get to Aretsou-Krini, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area.

To get to Komninon Street, you can walk from the seafront or take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square. Get off at Komninon Street.

Both areas have plenty of amenities, including beaches, cafes, and shops. Aretsou-Krini is particularly popular for its beach and water sports, while Komninon Street is known for its lively atmosphere and nightlife.

If you're looking for a more relaxed atmosphere, you can also visit the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada. These beaches are a bit further away from the city center, but are still easily accessible by bus or taxi.

Additionally, you can visit the Thessaloniki Marina, which is located in Aretsou-Krini. The marina offers a range of amenities, including boat tours and water sports.

Overall, Kalamaria is a great area to explore, with plenty of options for sightseeing, shopping, and nightlife. With its convenient location and range of amenities, it's an ideal destination for solo travelers like you.
reference: Some popular areas in Kalamaria include Aretsou and Krini, which stretch along the seafront and feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas. To get to these areas, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square and get off at the Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area.

user_input: What are the key attractions and features of Kalamaria, and how does it compare to the suburb of Panorama in Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).', 'FERAIOU

72', '65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN

response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb of Thessaloniki known for its beautiful beaches, waterfront, and vibrant shopping and dining scene. It's a great place for leisure activities like swimming, sunbathing, and people-watching. The suburb is also home to a variety of cafes, bars, and restaurants, including fish tavernas that are popular with locals and tourists alike.

In comparison, Panorama is another suburb of Thessaloniki that's also popular with tourists, but it has a more laid-back and natural atmosphere. Panorama is known for its mountainous terrain, which offers great hiking and biking opportunities, as well as its scenic views of the city. The suburb is also home to a variety of natural attractions, including the Vlatadon Monastery and the Mt. Chortiatis mountain.

While both suburbs offer a range of attractions and activities, Kalamaria is generally more geared towards leisure and entertainment, with its beautiful beaches and vibrant shopping and dining scene. Panorama, on the other hand, is more focused on outdoor activities and natural attractions.

That being said, both suburbs have their own unique charm and character, and they both offer a great experience for visitors. If you're looking for a more relaxed and natural atmosphere, Panorama might be the better choice. But if you're looking for a more vibrant and lively atmosphere, Kalamaria is definitely worth considering.

In terms of accessibility, both suburbs are easily accessible by public transportation, with bus lines connecting them to the city center. Additionally, both suburbs have a range of accommodations, including hotels and apartments, that cater to a variety of budgets and preferences.

Overall, both Kalamaria and Panorama are great options for visitors to Thessaloniki, and they both offer a unique and enjoyable experience. Whether you prefer the laid-back atmosphere of Panorama or the vibrant atmosphere of Kalamaria, there's something for everyone in these two suburbs.
reference:
Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a popular destination year-round. The main street, Komninon, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square.

In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It was uninhabited until the early 20th century, with its first inhabitants being refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Panorama is also known for its natural attractions, such as Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way. Both areas provide unique experiences, with Kalamaria focusing on coastal activities and nightlife, while Panorama emphasizes residential luxury and natural beauty.

These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The

2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along

square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the

From the direction of the

Palace. It covers a 12,500 
m2 area and it used to be 
the largest and the most 
important construction (next 
to Parthenon, Athens) of the 
Hellenic Classical Antiquity. 
This two-storeyed edifice 
is presumed to be the work 
of Pytheos who was the 
architect of the Mausoleum 
of Halicarnassos [modern-day 
Bodrum, Turkey], one of the 7 
wonders of the ancient world. 
The palace’s architectural style 
is considered avant-garde for 
that time and it was built of 
limestone during the 2nd half 
of the 4th c. BC on a plateau;

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb of Thessaloniki with a range of attractions and facilities to suit all interests. The main attractions include the Aretsou-Krini beach and the waterfront N. Plastira Street, lined with café-bars and fish tavernas. The area is also home to the Aretsou-Krini beach, where you can enjoy water sports and activities.

For those interested in history and culture, the Komninon Street is a must-visit, with its pedestrian-only street lined with shops, cafes, and restaurants. The area is also home to the church of the Transfiguration of Christ and the Town Hall.

For sports enthusiasts, the Kaftanzogleio National Stadium and the Poseidonio Sports Centre offer a range of facilities, including swimming pools, basketball, tennis, and handball fields. The stadium is also home to the Thessaloniki State Symphony Orchestra, which performs at the Thessaloniki Concert Hall.

Other attractions in Kalamaria include the Thessaloniki International Trade Fair, the National Theatre of Northern Greece, and the Kalamaria Municipal Theatre. The area is also home to a range of traditional markets, including the Kapani (Vlali Marketplace) and the Modiano Marketplace.

To access these attractions and facilities, visitors can use the local public transportation system, which includes buses and trains. The Long Distance Bus Station and the New Railway Station are also convenient options for getting around the city.

Overall, Kalamaria offers a range of attractions and facilities that cater to all interests and preferences. Whether you're looking for history, culture, sports, or entertainment, Kalamaria has something for everyone. With its convenient location and range of public transportation options, Kalamaria is an ideal destination for solo travelers and those looking for a budget-friendly experience.
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. To access these areas, bus lines 5 and 5A depart from Eleftherias square, with stops at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] or Chamodrakas in the Aretsou area.

['Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.

Monastery.
110', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105

website:

BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '85
DAY EXCURSIONS
Aravissou springs (15 km 
NW) where you can enjoy a 
meal at the local tavernas;  
the artificial Platanopotamos 
Lake, near Agrosykia village, 
(17 km NE) where you 
can visit the ruins of Pelit 
fortress, dating to the times 
of Alexander the Great, and 
Profitis Ilias country chapel; 
and the recreation area in 
Dytiko plane-tree forest (3.5 
km NE of Agrosykia village).
How to get there. Ancient 
Pella is located 40 km W of 
Thessaloniki. If you go by car, 
take the national road towards 
Edessa town and then follow 
the signs that will lead you 
to the archaeological site. To 
reach the military Museum of 
Balkan Wars, take the 68 bus 
departing from the station at 
the horseshoe-shaped point 
on Aristotelous Street (where 
Aristotelous and Egnatia 
Streets meet).
2 	\x07VERGINA  
(AIGES or AIGAI)
As far back as the 10th -8th 
c. BC Aiges was already a great  
town and the capital of the 
Macedon state until the 5th BC  
when King Archelaos moved 
the capital to Pella. It was 
situated in the centre of 
the area which was called 
“Macedonian Land” by 
Herodotus [an ancient Greek 
Historian].', 'IKEA station. 
If you travel by car, head for 
the airport and then follow 
Michanionas, Miaouli and 
Epanomis country roads.
7 	NEA MICHANIONA
A major fishing centre (32 
km S of Thessaloniki) with 
the largest fleet of deep sea 
fish boats in Greece! Once a 
refugee settlement, it is now a 
steadily growing area. The fish 
pier building by the picturesque 
harbour gets crowded especially 
during the early morning hours. 
Τhe seafront road is lined with 
café-bars and tavernas. Popular 
beaches in this area such as 
Tourbani and Angelochori have 
been awarded the Blue Flag  
for their beach quality.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Angelochori.
This small village lies 4 km  
N. of Nea Michaniona. 
Cape Megalo Emvolo (or 
Megalo Karampournou) 
affords a wonderful view of 
the Olympus massif. It is 
worth noticing the particular 
architectural structure of the 
remaining parts of an ottoman 
stronghold, built there in 1884 
by German civil engineers; 
there is also a lighthouse 
reaching a height of 10.50 m.  
75. Nea 
Michaniona 
is one of 
the greatest 
fisheries in 
Greece.
76. Peraia 
beach.
77. View of 
the seafront at 
Neoi Epivates.
78.']

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Chalkidiki is known for its beautiful beaches, and there are several popular ones to visit. One of the most famous is Kassandra Beach, which is approximately 110 km from Thessaloniki. It's a great spot for swimming and beach volleyball. Another popular beach is Sithonia Beach, located about 110 km from Thessaloniki as well. It's known for its calm waters and scenic views.

If you're looking for a more secluded experience, you can head to Agio Oros Beach, which is about 120 km from Thessaloniki. It's a great spot for those who want to get away from the crowds and enjoy the natural beauty of the area.

Lastly, if you're interested in visiting a beach that's a bit closer to Thessaloniki, you can try the beaches in the Asprovalta area. Nea Vrasna Beach is about 20 km from Thessaloniki, and it's a great spot for swimming and sunbathing.

All of these beaches offer a great experience, and they're easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Whether you're looking for a relaxing day at the beach or an action-packed day of swimming and beach volleyball, Chalkidiki has something for everyone. So pack your bags, grab your sunscreen, and head to Chalkidiki for an unforgettable beach vacation!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their stunning scenery and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

and the recreation area in

Pella is located 40 km W of 
Thessaloniki. If you go by car, 
take the national road towards 
Edessa town and then follow 
the signs that will lead you 
to the archaeological site. To 
reach the military Museum of 
Balkan Wars, take the 68 bus 
departing from the station at 
the horseshoe-shaped point 
on Aristotelous Street (where 
Aristotelous and Egnatia 
Streets meet).

A major fishing centre (32

the largest fleet of deep sea

pier building by the picturesque

beaches in this area such as

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
You can visit the beautiful beaches of Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos, which are all part of the Chalkidiki region. Kassandra is about 110 km north of Thessaloniki, while Sithonia is approximately 60 km north of Thessaloniki. Athos is a bit further away, about 120 km north of Thessaloniki.

Kassandra is a popular beach destination with many options to choose from, including the Blue Flag-awarded beaches of Aretsou and Nea Vrasna. Sithonia is known for its picturesque villages, beautiful beaches, and scenic views.

If you're looking for a more secluded experience, Athos offers stunning beaches with crystal-clear waters and picturesque villages to explore. However, please note that Athos is a monastic region, and visitors are expected to dress modestly and respect local customs.

All three regions offer a range of accommodations, from budget-friendly hotels to luxury resorts, so you can choose the one that suits your preferences.

In terms of accessibility, all three regions are easily accessible by car or bus from Thessaloniki. Just be aware that traffic can get busy during peak season, so plan your trip accordingly.

For Instagram-worthy spots, Kassandra is a must-visit, with its stunning beaches and picturesque villages. Sithonia is also a great option, with its scenic views and traditional villages.

Overall, Chalkidiki offers a range of amazing beaches and experiences, and I'm sure you'll have a wonderful time exploring this beautiful region!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their scenic beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

makes this cave one of the

4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for

It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105

response:
Chalkidiki has some amazing beaches that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular ones:

*   Kassandra Beach: This is one of the most popular beaches in Chalkidiki, known for its white sand and crystal-clear waters. It's about 20 km north of Thessaloniki, so it's relatively easy to get to by car or bus.
*   Sithonia Beach: Located in the Sithonia Peninsula, this beach is known for its picturesque views and calm waters. It's about 25 km north of Thessaloniki, so it's a bit further away than Kassandra Beach, but still easily accessible.
*   Agios Oros Beach: This beach is located in the Agio Oros region, which is known for its natural beauty and historic significance. It's about 30 km north of Thessaloniki, so it's a bit further away, but still worth visiting.
*   Asprovalta Beach: This beach is located in the Asprovalta region, which is known for its natural beauty and scenic views. It's about 40 km north of Thessaloniki, so it's a bit further away, but still easily accessible.

All of these beaches are easily accessible by car or bus, and they offer a range of amenities such as restaurants, bars, and water sports. They're also relatively affordable, making them a great option for budget-conscious travelers.

If you're looking for a more relaxing experience, you can also consider visiting some of the smaller beaches in the area, such as the ones in the Agio Oros region or the Asprovalta region. These beaches are often less crowded and offer a more peaceful atmosphere, making them ideal for solo travelers or couples looking for a romantic getaway.

Overall, Chalkidiki has a wide range of beaches to suit all tastes and preferences, and they're all easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Whether you're looking for a lively beach scene or a more relaxing experience, Chalkidiki has something for everyone.
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beautiful beaches are well-known for their scenic views and are a great destination for swimming.
