['Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:

(Administration Building),

tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', 'IKEA station. 
If you travel by car, head for 
the airport and then follow 
Michanionas, Miaouli and 
Epanomis country roads.
7 	NEA MICHANIONA
A major fishing centre (32 
km S of Thessaloniki) with 
the largest fleet of deep sea 
fish boats in Greece! Once a 
refugee settlement, it is now a 
steadily growing area. The fish 
pier building by the picturesque 
harbour gets crowded especially 
during the early morning hours. 
Τhe seafront road is lined with 
café-bars and tavernas. Popular 
beaches in this area such as 
Tourbani and Angelochori have 
been awarded the Blue Flag  
for their beach quality.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Angelochori.
This small village lies 4 km  
N. of Nea Michaniona. 
Cape Megalo Emvolo (or 
Megalo Karampournou) 
affords a wonderful view of 
the Olympus massif. It is 
worth noticing the particular 
architectural structure of the 
remaining parts of an ottoman 
stronghold, built there in 1884 
by German civil engineers; 
there is also a lighthouse 
reaching a height of 10.50 m.  
75. Nea 
Michaniona 
is one of 
the greatest 
fisheries in 
Greece.
76. Peraia 
beach.
77. View of 
the seafront at 
Neoi Epivates.
78.', 'Following the central 
European architectural trend of 
the time, the main building is  
a three storey construction with 
elaborate interior decoration 
and has access to a tower. 
Prince Nicholas, the city’s first 
Greek military commander, was 
accommodated here in 1912; 
in 1916-1917 E. Venizelos 
stayed in the villa as head of 
the temporary revolutionary 
Government of National Defence. 
In 1928 the building was bought 
by the National Bank of Greece 
and during the years 1938 – 
1961 it housed some of the city’s 
highschools. Since 1989, this  
is the location of the Thessaloniki  
Cultural Centre of the National 
Bank of Greece Cultural 
Foundation (MIET, see p. 77). 
Next to it there is a red brick 
castle, known as Chateau mon 
bonheur, dating to 1890.
3.6  Ahmet Kapanci Villa 
(105, Vas. Olgas Ave.).
It was built in 1905 by P. 
Arrigoni, as a country (seaside) 
residence for Ahmet Kapanci,  
a Jewish merchant and Mayor 
of the City. The architectural 
style is a mixed one as the 
eclectic features combine 
neoclassical, renaissance, art 
nouveau and gothic motifs.  
In 1926, the Greek State took 
ownership and since then 
the premises housed the Red 
Cross, the Gestapo, and NATO 
services until 1973.']

You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. response:
The beaches of Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos are easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Some popular options include:
- Kassandra: A lively beach with a variety of amenities, such as restaurants, bars, and water sports.
- Sithonia: A quieter beach with a more relaxed atmosphere, perfect for those seeking a peaceful getaway.
- Athos: A scenic beach with a beautiful lighthouse and stunning views of the surrounding area.

These beaches are easily accessible by car or bus from Thessaloniki, making them ideal for a weekend getaway. Additionally, they offer a range of amenities and activities, such as swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.

If you're looking for something a bit more off the beaten path, consider visiting the beaches of Nea Michaniona or Angelochori. These beaches are a bit further from Thessaloniki, but still easily accessible by car or bus. They offer a more secluded and peaceful atmosphere, perfect for those seeking a relaxing beach experience.

Overall, the beaches of Halkidiki are a must-visit for any traveler looking to escape the hustle and bustle of Thessaloniki. With their stunning natural beauty, range of amenities, and easy accessibility, they offer the perfect combination of relaxation and adventure.

Some Instagrammable spots to consider include:
- The iconic lighthouse at Cape Megalo Emvolo
- The picturesque village of Angelochori
- The stunning views of the seafront at Neoi Epivates

These spots are sure to make your beach experience in Halkidiki an unforgettable one!
reference: Some popular beaches in Halkidiki that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a 60 to 90-minute distance from the city. Specific beaches mentioned are in the Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros.

user_input: What are some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?

['Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building),

website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA

2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '85
DAY EXCURSIONS
Aravissou springs (15 km 
NW) where you can enjoy a 
meal at the local tavernas;  
the artificial Platanopotamos 
Lake, near Agrosykia village, 
(17 km NE) where you 
can visit the ruins of Pelit 
fortress, dating to the times 
of Alexander the Great, and 
Profitis Ilias country chapel; 
and the recreation area in 
Dytiko plane-tree forest (3.5 
km NE of Agrosykia village).
How to get there. Ancient 
Pella is located 40 km W of 
Thessaloniki. If you go by car, 
take the national road towards 
Edessa town and then follow 
the signs that will lead you 
to the archaeological site. To 
reach the military Museum of 
Balkan Wars, take the 68 bus 
departing from the station at 
the horseshoe-shaped point 
on Aristotelous Street (where 
Aristotelous and Egnatia 
Streets meet).
2 	\x07VERGINA  
(AIGES or AIGAI)
As far back as the 10th -8th 
c. BC Aiges was already a great  
town and the capital of the 
Macedon state until the 5th BC  
when King Archelaos moved 
the capital to Pella. It was 
situated in the centre of 
the area which was called 
“Macedonian Land” by 
Herodotus [an ancient Greek 
Historian].', 'IKEA station. 
If you travel by car, head for 
the airport and then follow 
Michanionas, Miaouli and 
Epanomis country roads.
7 	NEA MICHANIONA
A major fishing centre (32 
km S of Thessaloniki) with 
the largest fleet of deep sea 
fish boats in Greece! Once a 
refugee settlement, it is now a 
steadily growing area. The fish 
pier building by the picturesque 
harbour gets crowded especially 
during the early morning hours. 
Τhe seafront road is lined with 
café-bars and tavernas. Popular 
beaches in this area such as 
Tourbani and Angelochori have 
been awarded the Blue Flag  
for their beach quality.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Angelochori.
This small village lies 4 km  
N. of Nea Michaniona. 
Cape Megalo Emvolo (or 
Megalo Karampournou) 
affords a wonderful view of 
the Olympus massif. It is 
worth noticing the particular 
architectural structure of the 
remaining parts of an ottoman 
stronghold, built there in 1884 
by German civil engineers; 
there is also a lighthouse 
reaching a height of 10.50 m.

A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
You can visit the beautiful beaches of Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos, which are located in the north of Chalkidiki. These beaches are known for their crystal-clear waters and golden sand.

The nearest beach to Thessaloniki is the beach in Kavala, which is approximately 100 km north of the city. However, I would recommend visiting the beaches in Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos, as they are more popular among tourists and offer a wider range of amenities.

Some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki include:

* Agio Oros beach in Sithonia, which is approximately 60 km north of Thessaloniki.
* Kassandra beach in Kassandra, which is approximately 80 km north of Thessaloniki.
* Sithonia beach in Sithonia, which is approximately 70 km north of Thessaloniki.
* Athos beach in Athos, which is approximately 90 km north of Thessaloniki.

These beaches offer a range of amenities, including restaurants, bars, and water sports. They are also well-maintained and offer a range of activities, such as swimming, sunbathing, and hiking.

If you're looking for a more secluded beach experience, you can consider visiting the beaches in the Agios Vasileios region, which is approximately 120 km north of Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their natural beauty and offer a range of activities, such as swimming, snorkeling, and hiking.

Overall, Chalkidiki offers a range of beautiful beaches that are perfect for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Whether you're looking for a relaxing beach experience or an action-packed adventure, Chalkidiki has something for everyone.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

['Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.']

A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is renowned for its beautiful beaches. Here are some popular ones to visit:
1. Kassandra Beach: This beach is approximately 30-40 km south of Thessaloniki. It's a long, sandy beach perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.
2. Sithonia Beach: Located about 40-50 km south of Thessaloniki, Sithonia Beach offers a more secluded and peaceful experience. It's ideal for those seeking a relaxing day by the sea.
3. Agios Panteleimonas Beach: Situated on Mount Athos, about 60-70 km southeast of Thessaloniki, Agios Panteleimonas Beach is a stunning beach with crystal-clear waters and a picturesque setting.
4. Nea Vrasna Beach: Approximately 60-70 km southeast of Thessaloniki, Nea Vrasna Beach is a popular spot for swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.
5. Aretsou Beach: Located in Kalamaria, about 15-20 km east of Thessaloniki, Aretsou Beach is a lively beach with clear waters, making it perfect for families and young travelers.

These beaches are easily accessible by car or public transportation from Thessaloniki. Keep in mind that traffic can get heavy during peak season, so it's best to plan ahead.

For a more leisurely experience, consider visiting the beaches in the Strymonian Gulf, such as Lake Koroneia and Lake Volvi, which are approximately 100-120 km northeast of Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a serene atmosphere and are perfect for those seeking a relaxing getaway.

Remember to check the current conditions and opening hours before visiting any of these beaches, and enjoy your beach-hopping adventure in Halkidiki!
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

with healing and cosmetic

The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Chalkidiki is known for its beautiful beaches, and there are several popular ones to visit. 

Firstly, Kassandra and Sithonia are two peninsulas that offer stunning beaches. Kassandra is particularly popular, with its long stretch of sandy beach and lively atmosphere. It's about a 30-40 minute drive from Thessaloniki.

Another great option is Agio Oros, also known as Holy Mount. It's a scenic beach that's perfect for those looking for a more relaxed atmosphere. It's about a 45-minute drive from Thessaloniki.

Lastly, the beaches in the Asprovalta area are also worth visiting. They offer a range of activities, including swimming, beach volleyball, and water sports. It's about a 1-hour drive from Thessaloniki.

All of these beaches are easily accessible by car or public transport, making them perfect for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. And, with their stunning scenery and lively atmosphere, they're sure to be Instagrammable spots.

If you're looking for a more secluded beach experience, there are also some beautiful beaches in the Lake Koroneia area. They offer a peaceful atmosphere and stunning views of the surrounding mountains. It's about a 1.5-hour drive from Thessaloniki.

Overall, Chalkidiki has a wide range of beaches to suit every taste and preference. Whether you're looking for lively atmosphere or a more relaxed experience, there's something for everyone. So, pack your bags and head to Chalkidiki for an unforgettable beach vacation!
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

gulf. You will find a marine

a day trip (it’s only a short

53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is a must-visit destination for any beach lover, and it's just a short drive from Thessaloniki. Here are some of the most popular beaches to visit in Halkidiki, along with their distances from Thessaloniki:

*   Kassandra Beach: This stunning beach is approximately 20 kilometers east of Thessaloniki. It's known for its crystal-clear waters, golden sand, and picturesque views.
*   Sithonia Beach: Located about 30 kilometers south of Thessaloniki, Sithonia Beach is a hidden gem. It's a long, sandy beach with clear waters, perfect for swimming and sunbathing.
*   Nea Vrasna Beach: This beach is about 40 kilometers east of Thessaloniki and is known for its stunning views of the surrounding mountains. It's a great spot for swimming, snorkeling, and relaxing.
*   Stavros Beach: Located about 50 kilometers east of Thessaloniki, Stavros Beach is a popular spot for beachgoers. It's known for its beautiful views, clear waters, and lively atmosphere.
*   Agio Oros Beach: This beach is about 60 kilometers south of Thessaloniki and is a favorite among locals and tourists alike. It's known for its stunning views, clear waters, and picturesque surroundings.

All of these beaches are easily accessible by car, and they offer a range of amenities, including restaurants, bars, and water sports. They're perfect for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki, and they're sure to provide you with an unforgettable beach experience.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas

110', '88
DAY EXCURSIONS
Jewish quarter in Europe, 
which maintains a traditional 
character in its entirety. It 
is worth taking a walk and 
visiting the Roman, Ottoman 
and Industrial age monuments 
in the traditional districts of 
Kyriotissa, Panagia Dexia, and 
Makariotissa; you can also visit 
the Public Central Library which 
has earned an international 
award, or relax in the parks  
and squares.
How to get there.  
Vergina is about 63 km SW  
of Thessaloniki. If you travel by 
car, follow the signs to Veroia 
and after that to Vergina. You 
can also take the intercity bus 
or the train to reach Veroia  
and then take the local bus  
to Vergina.
3 	DION
This most enchanting 
archaeological site is  
located under the imposing 
Olympus mountain range, in  
a 150-hectare green area amid 
flowing waters coming from 
Vafyras River and from other 
springs; it is the habitat of 
many species of birds, reptiles 
and amphibians. This used to 
be a sacred place to ancient 
Macedonians who worshipped 
Olympian Zeus and the Muses 
[daughters of Zeus] here.', 'In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans. There are 
swimming pools for men 
and women, 10 personal 
hydromassage areas where 
mineral spring water is used, 
saunas, a gym and areas 
for mud treatment. In the 
summer, visitors can enjoy 
a special mud therapy by 
the lake shore which gets 
usually dried up during the 
warmest season of the year. 
In the grounds you will find 
a physiotherapy centre and 
a medical clinic, a hotel, a 
restaurant, a bar, basketball 
and football fields.
How to get there. 
Pikrolimni is located 23 
km N of Thessaloniki. If 
you travel by car, follow the 
signs to Kilkis and after that, 
from Galliko village head 
for Xylokeratia (Pikrolimni). 
Alternatively there is a bus 
from Dimokratias square 
(Vardari) leaving daily at 9 am, 
which will take you to the Mud 
Therapy Centre for free.
DAY EXCURSIONS

A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki offers a plethora of beautiful beaches that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki. 

One of the most popular beaches is Kassandra Beach, located approximately 110 km south of Thessaloniki. This beach is known for its crystal-clear waters, golden sand, and lively atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for families and couples alike.

Another notable beach is Sithonia Beach, situated about 120 km south of Thessaloniki. This beach is famous for its picturesque views, calm waters, and scenic surroundings, making it perfect for those seeking a more relaxed atmosphere.

Additionally, Agio Oros Beach, located approximately 130 km south of Thessaloniki, is a hidden gem that offers stunning views, crystal-clear waters, and a tranquil atmosphere, making it an excellent choice for those seeking a peaceful retreat.

All three beaches are easily accessible by car or bus, and they offer a range of amenities, including restaurants, cafes, and water sports facilities.

If you're looking for a more secluded experience, you can consider visiting the beaches along the Chalkidiki Peninsula, such as Agios Ioannis Beach or Panagia Beach. These beaches are located approximately 150-200 km south of Thessaloniki and offer a more peaceful atmosphere, perfect for those seeking a tranquil getaway.

Overall, Halkidiki's beaches offer a range of experiences, from lively and family-friendly to secluded and peaceful. Whether you're looking for crystal-clear waters, golden sand, or stunning views, there's a beach in Halkidiki that's perfect for you.
reference: The notable beaches in Halkidiki that travelers can visit include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are renowned for their scenic beauty and are a great option for those looking to enjoy a swim and relax by the sea.

user_input: What historical significance does Thessaloniki's Old Town hold in relation to its Macedonian heritage and how does it connect to the Roman Forum?
retrieved_contexts:
['It was 
situated in the centre of 
the area which was called 
“Macedonian Land” by 
Herodotus [an ancient Greek 
Historian]. The first magnificent 
palaces of the Macedonian 
Kings were built here and 
the foundations of the great 
Macedon State were laid at 
that time. It was the sacred 
town of the Macedonians 
and remained so after the 
5th c. BC as Aiges was the 
place of origin of the Royal 
House of Argeades whose 
members were thought to be 
descendants of the House 
of Timenides and Hercules. 
In 168 BC the town was 
destroyed by the Romans and 
finally got deserted in the 1st 
c. AD. On the grounds of its 
importance, the archaeological 
site has been included in the 
UNESCO World Heritage List 
as a Multiple Thematic Focus 
Museum.
MUST SEE:
Royal Tombs. In 1977, 
the archaeologist Manolis 
Andronikos unearthed the 
royal tombs inside a big earth 
mound (Megali Toumpa - 
Great Tumulus). The tombs 
and the mound interior have 
been restructured into an 
amazing museum where the 
99
100', 'Greek revolts 
of that period in Macedonia are 
described in Room A; exhibits 
related to the Macedonian 
society of the late 19th c. are 
in Room B; a reconstruction 
of the office of the Greek 
General Consul is in Room C; 
the process of recruitment in 
the Greek guerilla forces of 
those times is on display in 
Room D; the role played by the 
clergy is depicted in Room E; 
the Balkan Wars are described 
in Room F; the course of 
Macedonian history following 
the Balkan Wars is in Room G. 
Costumes and authentic relics 
from the Balkan Wars Period 
(arms, uniforms among other 
items), are exhibited in the 
1st floor, as is a collection of 
miniature vehicles of the Greek 
army.
WAR MUSEUM
Exhibits include objects 
such as uniforms, arms, maps, 
battleship effigies, documents 
and military decorations, 
which are connected with the 
most significant events of the 
modern Greek history, from the 
1821 War of Independence 
until the 1944 liberation from 
the German Occupation forces. 
In the museum’s courtyard you 
will see armoured vehicles, 
fighters and torpedoes used by 
the Greek Army in the past.
ATATURK MUSEUM 
Exhibits occupy two floors: 
The 1st floor includes the 
parlour, the living room, the 
85 & 86. 
(left) The 
neoclassical 
building of 
the Museum 
for the 
Macedonian 
Struggle and 
(right) one of 
its exhibits.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '90
DAY EXCURSIONS
Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.  
In the West side there were 
the luxury houses of Epigenis 
and Evvoulos, decorated with 
exquisite mosaics; Sevasteio, 
a temple dedicated to 
the worship of the Roman 
emperors was situated in 
between the houses. In the 
East side, there is a roman 
basilica, an area for trade  
and banking transactions,  
the Monument of the Shields 
(with shield and cuirass 
depictions) and the Forum 
Thermae.
Polygonal building.', '36
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”).']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is steeped in historical significance, particularly in relation to its Macedonian heritage. The area has been the hub of the city since its founding in the 4th century BC, and it has been associated with great empires, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Rule. The Old Town is home to numerous monuments, dating from various historical periods, which coexist in a singular and charming way, manifesting Thessaloniki's multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

The Macedonian heritage is deeply connected to the Roman Forum, which dates back to the late 2nd – early 3rd century AD. The forum was a significant center of commerce, culture, and politics during the Roman period, and it features various structures, including a colonnaded archway, known as the "Enchanted Ones" or "Stoa of the Statuettes". This archway is decorated with figures in relief, both inside and outside, and it is a testament to the city's rich cultural and historical past.

The Roman Forum is also connected to the Old Town's history through the Great Thermae, a complex of public bath houses that dates back to the 2nd century AD. The Great Thermae features Vespasian urinals, entertainment areas, and a courtyard, showcasing the advanced engineering and architectural skills of the Roman civilization.

In the context of Thessaloniki's Macedonian heritage, the Roman Forum is significant because it represents the city's transition from a Macedonian to a Roman city. The forum's architecture and layout reflect the Roman influence on the city, while the Macedonian heritage is still visible in the area's layout and the presence of the "Enchanted Ones" archway.

Overall, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, offering a glimpse into the city's complex and fascinating past. Visitors can explore the Roman Forum, the Great Thermae, and other monuments to gain a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's historical evolution. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and narrow alleys. This atmosphere has attracted artists and students, emphasizing its cultural importance. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage by highlighting the city's historical role as a significant urban center in Macedonia. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century further illustrate the layered history of Thessaloniki, linking its Macedonian roots to its Roman past.

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in

historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance in relation to its Macedonian heritage, as it was the site of the ancient city of Thessalonica, which was founded by Cassander in the 4th century BC. The city was an important centre of the Macedonian State, and its multicultural history is associated with great empires, including the Romans, Byzantines, and Ottomans.

The Old Town is particularly notable for its connections to the Roman Forum, which dates back to the late 2nd - early 3rd century AD. The forum was built during the Roman period and features a range of impressive buildings, including the Great Thermae, the Houses of Zosa and Lida, and the Roman Forum itself. The forum was a major hub of activity in ancient Thessalonica, and its ruins provide valuable insights into the city's history and culture.

One of the most significant historical sites in the Old Town is the White Tower, which was built in the 4th century BC and served as the city's defensive stronghold. The tower has been beautifully restored and now houses the Museum of the White Tower, which features a range of exhibits on the city's history and culture.

The Old Town is also home to a number of other historical sites, including the Archaeological Museum, which houses a range of artifacts from the city's ancient past. The museum is particularly notable for its collection of mosaics, which provide valuable insights into the city's art and culture.

Overall, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history and culture. Its connections to the Roman Forum and its rich Macedonian heritage make it a unique and fascinating place to explore. Visitors can easily spend a weekend exploring the Old Town's many historical sites, and its accessibility makes it easy for solo travelers to navigate.

In terms of Instagrammable spots, the Old Town is a photographer's paradise, with its picturesque streets, historic buildings, and beautiful architecture. Visitors can easily capture stunning photos of the White Tower, the Roman Forum, and other historical sites, making it a great destination for social media enthusiasts.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and students. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, further emphasizes the historical depth of Thessaloniki. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century highlight the city's evolution through different eras, including its Macedonian roots.

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern

a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is deeply rooted in its Macedonian heritage, with the city's history dating back to the 4th century BC. The area is home to numerous monuments and structures that reflect its multicultural past, including the White Tower, which was built during the Byzantine era and later modified by the Ottomans. The city's strategic location along the Via Egnatia, a major trade route, facilitated its growth into a significant urban center.

The Old Town's connection to the Roman Forum is evident in its history as a major hub of trade and commerce. The forum, which dates back to the 2nd-3rd centuries AD, was an important center of Roman activity in the city. The area was home to several notable buildings, including the Great Thermae, the Houses of Zosa and Lida, and the Roman Forum itself. These structures demonstrate the city's importance as a major center of Roman culture and commerce.

The Old Town's Macedonian heritage is also reflected in its archaeological sites, such as the Megali Toumpa, which houses the royal tombs of the Macedonian Kings. This site provides a glimpse into the city's rich history and the cultural significance of the Macedonian monarchy.

Visitors to the Old Town can explore these historical sites, gaining a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's complex cultural heritage. The area's rich history and architecture make it an ideal destination for those interested in exploring the city's Macedonian roots and its connection to the Roman Empire.

As a solo traveler, you can easily navigate the Old Town's narrow streets and alleys, taking in the sights and sounds of this historic area. With its rich history and cultural significance, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's heritage.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and intellects. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage as it highlights the city's historical importance from ancient times through the Byzantine era, further enriching the cultural tapestry of Thessaloniki.

DAY EXCURSIONS
Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.

Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.']

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of history and culture, with a rich legacy that dates back to the 4th century BC. As the capital of Macedonia, it has been shaped by various civilizations, including the ancient Greeks, Romans, and Byzantines. The Old Town is home to numerous landmarks, such as the White Tower Museum, which showcases the city's Roman past, and the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which features an impressive collection of artifacts from the Iron Age to the Byzantine era.

The Roman Forum, located in the heart of the Old Town, is a significant archaeological site that bears testament to Macedonia's cultural heritage. This ancient complex was once the center of commerce, politics, and social life in the city, with various buildings, temples, and monuments that reflect the cultural and artistic achievements of the Roman Empire.

The Roman Forum is particularly significant in the context of Macedonia's cultural heritage, as it was the site of numerous cultural and artistic achievements, including the construction of impressive buildings, temples, and monuments. The forum was also the center of trade and commerce, with merchants and traders from all over the Mediterranean coming to the city to buy and sell goods.

The Roman Forum's historical significance is further underscored by the fact that it was the site of the "Enchanted Ones," a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with Corinthian-order columns and pillars, which is now known as the Stoa of the Statuettes. This ancient structure is a testament to the cultural and artistic achievements of the Roman Empire and provides a glimpse into the city's rich cultural heritage.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of history and culture, with a rich legacy that dates back to the 4th century BC. The Roman Forum is a significant archaeological site that bears testament to Macedonia's cultural heritage, and its historical significance is further underscored by the fact that it was the site of numerous cultural and artistic achievements, including the construction of impressive buildings, temples, and monuments.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it has remained largely untouched since the 1917 great fire and showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. It was settled by the Ottomans in the mid-15th century due to its favorable climate and strategic position. The Roman Forum, on the other hand, served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. Both sites reflect the rich cultural heritage of Macedonia, illustrating the city's evolution through different historical periods and influences.

Government” in Thessaloniki, 
which remained there for 
several months.

99
100', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1.

area is one of the 
busiest parts of

(Nikis Ave.) meets

waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.

WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects 
Thessaloniki with the rest of 
Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul; 
it is also the bus terminus 
towards most of the city areas. 
This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it is exclusively 
used as a cargo train station. 
This is where the German 
occupation forces mustered 
about 50,000 Jewish residents, 
from March until August 1943, 
in order to send them by train 
off to concentration camps.
2.3  Top Hane (Vardariou 
Tower).
Situated where the west 
and seafront city walls used 
to meet, this Tower was built 
by the Ottomans in 1546 and 
it was known as the Armoury 
Tower. It is a six-sided, three-
storey and 10-metre high tower 
which used to be the main city 
stronghold.']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance in relation to its Macedonian heritage due to its connection to the ancient city of Aiges, the sacred town of the Macedonians, and the Royal Tombs. The Royal Tombs, discovered in 1977, are a testament to the city's rich Macedonian past and are now part of the Multiple Thematic Focus Museum, showcasing the archaeological site's importance. The Old Town's history is deeply intertwined with the Macedonian State, which was founded in the area by Herodotus.

The Roman Forum, on the other hand, plays a lesser role in Thessaloniki's development, as it is primarily associated with the city's later history under Roman rule. The Roman Forum was established after the destruction of the ancient city of Aiges, and its significance lies in its connection to the Roman Empire's influence on the city.

However, the Roman Forum does serve as a reminder of Thessaloniki's complex history, which has been shaped by various empires and cultures, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman. The city's multicultural nature is reflected in the Roman Forum's architecture and layout, which coexist with other historical monuments, such as the White Tower and the Top Hane Tower.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town holds a more significant connection to its Macedonian heritage, while the Roman Forum plays a more minor role in the city's development. Nevertheless, both historical sites contribute to the city's rich cultural and historical landscape, making Thessaloniki a fascinating destination for those interested in exploring its complex past.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and architectural features. This historical context is further enriched by the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period. Constructed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Forum highlights the city's importance in the region and its evolution over time, linking the Macedonian past with the Roman influence that shaped Thessaloniki's development.

Parts of a colonnade, mosaic

Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.  
In the West side there were 
the luxury houses of Epigenis 
and Evvoulos, decorated with 
exquisite mosaics; Sevasteio, 
a temple dedicated to 
the worship of the Roman 
emperors was situated in 
between the houses. In the 
East side, there is a roman 
basilica, an area for trade  
and banking transactions,  
the Monument of the Shields 
(with shield and cuirass 
depictions) and the Forum
