Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance, particularly in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage. The forum dates back to the late 2nd - early 3rd century AD and was the social and religious centre of the city during the Roman period. Although it was abandoned after the 7th century, its remains still offer valuable insights into the city's history and its transformation under Roman rule.

Interestingly, the forum was built on top of the ancient city of Thessaloniki, which was originally called the "Macedonian Land" by Herodotus. The city's strategic location made it an attractive spot for various civilizations, including the Romans, who later transformed it into a thriving metropolis.

The Roman Forum's presence in Thessaloniki is also a testament to the city's cultural exchange and syncretism. The forum's architecture, with its arcades and public buildings, reflects the blending of Roman and Greek styles. This cultural fusion is a hallmark of Thessaloniki's rich history, which has been shaped by various empires and civilizations.

Furthermore, the Roman Forum is closely tied to the city's Macedonian heritage through its connection to the Royal House of Argeades. According to historical records, the forum was built during the reign of the Roman emperor Vespasian, who was also the patron deity of the city's patron deity Asklipios. The forum's design and layout also reflect the city's status as a major centre of trade and commerce, which was a key aspect of the Macedonian state.

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage, offering a glimpse into the city's transformation under Roman rule and its cultural exchange with other civilizations. Its presence serves as a testament to Thessaloniki's rich history and its status as a major centre of trade and commerce.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, reflects the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it showcases the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

['42
Thessaloniki’s Old Town is 
full of atmosphere. It covers 
the area in between the city 
walls (to the north and east) 
and Olympiados Street (to 
the south), and has had the 
luck to remain untouched by 
the 1917 great fire. It was 
virtually uninhabited until 
the mid-15th century, when 
it was conquered by the 
Ottomans who selected it for 
settlement on account of its 
fine climate, panoramic views 
and strategic position. The 
two and three-storey houses 
bear mixed Macedonian 
and Ottoman architectural 
elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş 
in turkish]; there are also 
residences with neoclassical 
and eclectic style motifs 
where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. 
converts to Islam who secretly 
remained Jews. After 1922 
many refugees settled in the 
area. Despite the construction 
of newer buildings and the 
opening up of new streets in 
recent decades, it has kept 
its original town planning, to 
a large extent, with narrow 
alleys and scant squares, as 
well as its original architectural 
features, particularly in the 
west and east part of the town. 
This particular atmosphere has 
lured intellects, artists 
and students who chose it  
for settlement in recent years.

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

6.3  The Jewish Museum 
of Thessaloniki.
It is housed in a 1904 historic 
building (V. Poselli), which 
survived the 1917 fire and is 
owned by Jews. There used to 
be a shopping arcade there, 
once, and it has –at times-

6.4  Venizelou street. 
A very busy street linking 
Eleftherias sq. with the 
Residency since 1867 (see p. 39). 
It is a shopping street lined 
with many interesting buildings 
of eclectic and art deco style, 
mostly up to Egnatia street 
(see p. 34). On the north side 
of the junction of Venizelou 
and Tsimiski streets, lies the 
Gategno-Florentin Building, a 
typical example of architectural

a four-floor building and fronts 
three streets.

1.5  YMCA Building.
This emblematic building 
(1934) houses the Young 
Men’s Christian Association 
of Thessaloniki. It bears a 
significant mixture of elements 
of neo-colonial and byzantine 
architecture. The building also 
houses Avlaia theatre; among 
the surrounding constructions 
are an outdoor basketball field 
and a tennis court, an indoor

In front of the building lies  
the small YMCA square.  
The Armenian Church (1903, 
V. Poselli) is at a very short 
distance, between Dialetti  
and Ant. Kamara Streets.
1.6  Archaeological 
Museum.
It was designed by P. 
Karantinos, a major Greek 
architect, and it was 
inaugurated in 1962. Inspired 
by the ancient Greek Revival 
Architectural style, it is 
considered as one of the most 
typical examples of modernist 
architectural design in Greece. 
An annex was added in 1980 
and in 2003 the museum  
was extensively remodelled  
to accommodate contemporary 
needs. There are rooms for 
periodic exhibitions, events 
and educational programmes, 
a café and a shop (see p.70  
for museum exhibits).']

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance due to its well-preserved architectural styles, which reflect the city's rich cultural heritage, particularly during the Ottoman period. The town's layout and buildings, such as the two and three-storey houses, showcase a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia). This blend of styles is a testament to the city's history as a major cultural and commercial center, attracting various ethnic and religious groups, including the Ottomans.

The Ottomans' influence on the town's architecture is evident in the use of elements such as arches, domes, and minarets, which were incorporated into the existing Macedonian structures. This fusion of styles resulted in a unique and fascinating architectural landscape, with many buildings still standing today.

The town's history, dating back to the 15th century, is also reflected in its narrow alleys and scant squares, which have remained largely intact. These features, combined with the town's original architectural features, have preserved the Old Town's original character and charm.

In terms of the Macedonian culture, the town's history during the Ottoman period is marked by the presence of various ethnic and religious groups, including the Dönmeh, who were converts to Islam. The town's architecture also reflects this cultural diversity, with buildings such as the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki, which was built in 1904 and features a mix of eclectic and art deco styles.

Overall, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, offering a unique glimpse into the city's rich cultural heritage and the influence of the Macedonian culture, particularly during the Ottoman period. Visitors can explore the town's narrow alleys, admire its well-preserved architecture, and learn about its fascinating history, making it an unforgettable experience.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it showcases a blend of architectural styles that reflect its Macedonian heritage and the influence of the Ottoman period. The area, which remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, features two and three-storey houses that exhibit mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, known as sachnisia. This unique combination of styles, along with neoclassical and eclectic motifs, highlights the town's rich cultural history. The settlement of the Ottomans in the mid-15th century, attracted by the region's fine climate and strategic position, further contributed to the architectural landscape, making it a vibrant center for intellects, artists, and students in recent years.

that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during

of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the

Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their

ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a 
reconstruction is attempted of 
a cemetery segment containing 
finds, sarcophagi and altars; 
the second one involves the 
re-creation of a Greco-roman 
house with mosaic floors on 
display and items of daily use.
• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The 
items exhibited refer to Man’s 
first productive stages in 
Macedonia (with activities such 
as hunting, fishing, agriculture, 
stock farming, weaving, 
metallurgy). There are also 
casts of skulls belonging to 
Ouranopithecus Macedoniensis, 
an early hominid primate, as 
well as of the Man found in 
Petralona cave (see p. 92).
• Temporary exhibitions. 
The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where 
particular aspects of every day 
life in Macedonia are treated in 
connection with the Greek and 
the Mediterranean area.
THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD.']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a historical site of significant importance, showcasing the city's rich history as a major center of the Roman Empire. The forum is a remnant of the city's Hellenistic and Roman past, featuring various structures and monuments that date back to the 1st – 4th c. AD. 

Architecturally, the forum is characterized by its Greco-roman style, with notable features such as the Odeon, a 2nd – 4th c. AD building used for cultural events, and the round bath house, which has been in use since the 1st c. BC. The forum also includes the "Enchanted Ones" (las Incantadas), a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with Corinthian-order columns and pillars, which is decorated with figures in relief. 

In relation to the architectural influences seen in Macedonia, the Roman Forum is a testament to the region's history as a province of the Roman Empire. The site showcases the fusion of Hellenistic and Roman styles, reflecting the cultural exchange and influences that occurred during this period. 

The forum's significance extends beyond its architectural beauty, as it provides insight into the daily lives and traditions of the people who lived and worked in the area. The site is also home to various artifacts and relics, including the remains of the ancient city, which offer a glimpse into the region's rich cultural heritage. 

Overall, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a historical site that offers a unique glimpse into the region's rich history and cultural significance. Its Greco-roman architecture and various monuments make it an essential destination for anyone interested in exploring the cultural and historical significance of Macedonia.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, showcases significant historical importance as it was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. This area reflects the architectural influences of the time, which can also be seen in the mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements present in Thessaloniki’s Old Town. The forum's gradual abandonment after the 7th century and the remnants of its structures, such as the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the city's rich historical tapestry, which is deeply intertwined with the broader architectural heritage of Macedonia.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a historical site that holds significant importance to the city's Macedonian heritage. Although the forum was built during the Roman period, it is situated in the heart of the ancient city of Thessaloniki, which was once the capital of the Macedonian Kingdom. The forum was constructed in two phases, with the first phase completed in the mid-2nd century AD and the second phase in the mid-3rd century AD. 

The forum was an important social and religious center of the city, and its layout reflects the city's strategic location. The forum was surrounded by arcades and public buildings, which were likely used for various purposes, including trade, banking, and worship. The forum also features several notable structures, such as the Monument of the Shields, which depicts shield and cuirass depictions, and the Basilica, which was likely used for religious purposes. 

The Roman Forum's historical significance is also tied to the city's Macedonian heritage, as it was built on the site of the ancient city of Thessaloniki, which was once the capital of the Macedonian Kingdom. The forum's construction and layout reflect the city's rich history and cultural significance. Additionally, the forum's features, such as the Monument of the Shields and the Basilica, are reminiscent of the city's ancient Macedonian heritage. 

The Roman Forum's importance to Thessaloniki's Macedonian heritage is further highlighted by its inclusion in the UNESCO World Heritage List, which recognizes its cultural and historical significance. The forum's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage Site acknowledges its importance to the city's history and cultural identity. 

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance to the city's Macedonian heritage, reflecting the city's rich history, cultural significance, and strategic location. Its features, such as the Monument of the Shields and the Basilica, are reminiscent of the city's ancient Macedonian heritage, and its inclusion in the UNESCO World Heritage List underscores its importance to the city's history and cultural identity.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, highlights the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it reflects the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, provide insight into the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '36
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”).', '72
MUSEUMS
by tradesmen. Aspects of

covering the times from

the post Byzantine period. 
The exhibition is structured 
by dates, in the following 
thematic categories:
• Early Christian or Early 
Byzantine period (4th–7th c.).

described, ii) Early christian

From the Elysian Fields to the

period (8th – 12th c.).', '57

NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE
3.12 Yeni Camii  
(New Mosque).
It is located at 30, Archaeolo-
gikou Mouseiou Street. It was 
built in 1902 by the Italian 
architect V. Poselli as the 
mosque for Jews converted  
to Islam (Donmeh). It combines 
features of the Muslim 
architectural tradition and 
eclecticism. In 1922 the building 
provided accommodation for 
refugees and during the period 
1925–1963 it housed the city’s 
Archaeological Museum. It is now 
a municipal exhibition area; in the 
yard there is a collection of marble 
sculptures dating to Roman and 
Early Christian times (sarcophagi, 
stelae and others), collected from 
the wider urban area. 
3.13 Hatzimisef Villa  
(3, Vas. Olgas Ave.)
This is yet another building 
typical of the style found in 
the area, housing the town’s 
1st High School. At no. 5, lies 
the Joseph Modiano villa, 
today uninhabited and barely 
discernible behind the fencing. 
A branch of the town’s 1st High 
School was once located here.
3.14 Bust of George I.

The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it provides insight into the early Christian period and its artistic expression. This mural, along with the numerous Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, showcases the city's rich Christian heritage and its importance in the Byzantine world.

Thessaloniki's Christian monuments, such as the Church of Agios Ioannis Prodromos and the Ascension of Christ church, demonstrate the city's significance in the early Christian period. The presence of these monuments, along with the early Christian mural in the Roman Forum, highlights Thessaloniki's role as a major center of Christianity during the Byzantine era.

The early Christian mural in the Roman Forum is a testament to the artistic expression of the early Christian period, featuring depictions of Christian themes and motifs. Its significance extends beyond its artistic value, as it provides a glimpse into the daily life and practices of early Christians.

The connection between the early Christian mural and Thessaloniki's Christian monuments is that they all reflect the city's importance in the Byzantine world. Thessaloniki's Christian monuments, including the Church of Agios Ioannis Prodromos and the Ascension of Christ church, demonstrate the city's significance in the early Christian period, while the early Christian mural in the Roman Forum provides insight into the artistic expression of that period.

Together, these monuments and the mural showcase Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its significance in the Byzantine world. They demonstrate the city's importance as a major center of Christianity during the Byzantine era and provide a glimpse into the daily life and practices of early Christians.

In summary, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it provides insight into the early Christian period and its artistic expression, and its connection to Thessaloniki's Christian monuments highlights the city's importance in the Byzantine world.

This mural, uncovered in a public storehouse, showcases the artistic expression of early Christianity. It relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which were constructed during the Byzantine period and reflect the city's historical importance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul. Both the mural and the monuments highlight Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the broader Byzantine world.

Sections of the city’s west walls  
remain along Arkadioupoleos and 
Eirinis Streets and finds related 
to Litaia Gate have recently 
been located at the corner 
of Agiou Dimitriou and Agiou 
Nestoros Streets. This gate 
used to be one of the seven 
great gates of the fortified city 
and formed part of the Early 
Christian period walls; it was 
named after Liti, a Byzantine 
town to which the gate led. 
The Golden Gate was also 
located on the Egnatia  
Street level.
2.8  Pasha Hamam  
[Paşa Hamami] (Phoenix  
Bath house).
It was built during the 
1520s by Cezeri Kasim Paşa. 
Also known as Phoenix Bath 
house, this used to be the 
last ottoman bath house open 
in town, as it closed down in 
as late as 1981. It is located 
at the corner of Kalvou and 
Pineiou Streets, near the west 
walls and the church of the 
Holy Twelve Apostles, and the 
structure of the building was 
planned with great care.', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.),

churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire

early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.

[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29).

around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', 'It is located 
at the corner of Kalvou and 
Pineiou Streets, near the west 
walls and the church of the 
Holy Twelve Apostles, and the 
structure of the building was 
planned with great care.
3 	 \x07
WEST OF THE 
HARBOUR
The area began to grow in 
the late 19th century, after the 
demolition of the seafront city 
wall and the ensuing pulling 
down of large sections of the 
city’s west and east walls. 
The short distance to the 
harbour and the rail system 
construction were two decisive 
factors which led to large 
industrial unit installations  
in the area. In recent decades 
many of these buildings 
were changed into culture 
and entertainment venues, 
while others are scheduled 
to become sports or cultural 
centres. An example would be 
the listed building of the old 
Municipal Slaughterhouse (early 
20th c.), near the FIX factory, 
after which the entire district 
was named. 
MUST SEE:
3.1  Vilka multi purpose 
venue.
This is the old textile factory 
of Torres and Co., renamed 
Vilka, which closed down in 
1988 and is now restructured 
into a space reserved for various 
events and entertainment, as it 
includes a theatre, concert halls, 
cafés and bars.
68
68.  
Mylos multi-
purpose 
venue is one 
of the most 
popular places 
for hosting 
events and 
entertainments 
in Thessaloniki.

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
In Thessaloniki, you can find significant Christian murals in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which dates back to the 4th-15th centuries. The church is a must-see for its well-preserved Byzantine architecture and stunning mosaics, including the iconic Ascension of Christ mural.

Nearby, the Roman Forum is home to several impressive Christian murals, including the Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, also known as Metamorfosi Sotiros. This church, built around 1340, features a typical example of the transitional type in Byzantine church-building.

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is particularly notable for its early-Christian baptistery, the Agia Sofia catacomb, built on the ruins of Roman baths. This hidden gem is a testament to the city's rich history and cultural heritage.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can also explore the Byzantine museum, which features an impressive collection of early-Christian and Byzantine monuments, including the famous Holy Twelve Apostles Church. The museum is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognized for its significant contributions to the Byzantine world.

When visiting Thessaloniki, solo travelers like yourself can immerse themselves in the city's rich Christian history and culture. The significant Christian murals and Byzantine architecture make for a truly unforgettable experience. Be sure to explore the city's many churches, museums, and historical sites to discover the fascinating stories behind these incredible works of art.

In terms of Instagrammable spots, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Byzantine museum are must-visits. The church's stunning mosaics and the museum's impressive collection make for breathtaking photographs. Don't forget to capture the city's vibrant atmosphere and historic landmarks, like the Roman Forum and the Palace of Galerius. With its rich history and cultural heritage, Thessaloniki is the perfect destination for any solo traveler seeking a unique and unforgettable experience.
reference: In Thessaloniki, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos (Mother of God) and the Founder, showcasing early Christian iconography. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center during the Roman period, contains a valuable early Christian mural uncovered in its underground Cryptoporticus, further highlighting the city's rich Christian heritage.

mosque for Jews converted  
to Islam (Donmeh). It combines 
features of the Muslim 
architectural tradition and 
eclecticism. In 1922 the building 
provided accommodation for 
refugees and during the period 
1925–1963 it housed the city’s 
Archaeological Museum. It is now 
a municipal exhibition area; in the 
yard there is a collection of marble 
sculptures dating to Roman and 
Early Christian times (sarcophagi, 
stelae and others), collected from 
the wider urban area. 
3.13 Hatzimisef Villa  
(3, Vas. Olgas Ave.)
This is yet another building 
typical of the style found in 
the area, housing the town’s 
1st High School. At no. 5, lies 
the Joseph Modiano villa, 
today uninhabited and barely 
discernible behind the fencing. 
A branch of the town’s 1st High 
School was once located here.
3.14 Bust of George I.
It is found at the corner 
of Vas. Olgas Ave. and Agias 
Triadas St. This is the spot 
where King George I was 
assassinated on March 5, 1913 
by Al.']

["<1-hop>

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it showcases the early Christian art and culture in Thessaloniki, which was an important city in the Byzantine Empire. This mural is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Monuments in Thessaloniki, highlighting the city's rich Christian heritage. The mural depicts scenes from the early Christian period, providing insight into the city's early Christian church and burial practices. In Thessaloniki, the Christian monuments, such as the Ascension of Christ and the baptistery of Agia Sofia, demonstrate the city's importance in the Byzantine Empire and its early Christian history. These monuments, like the early Christian mural, are a testament to the city's unique cultural and historical significance. The early Christian mural in the Roman Forum is a tangible representation of Thessaloniki's early Christian art and culture, reinforcing the city's connection to the Byzantine Empire and its Christian heritage. By studying the early Christian mural and the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, one can gain a deeper understanding of the city's rich history and cultural significance. The early Christian mural in the Roman Forum serves as a reminder of the importance of preserving and celebrating Thessaloniki's cultural and historical heritage. 

The significance of the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki because both share a common history and cultural significance. The early Christian mural in the Roman Forum provides insight into the early Christian art and culture in Thessaloniki, while the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki demonstrate the city's importance in the Byzantine Empire and its early Christian history. Both are a testament to Thessaloniki's unique cultural and historical significance, highlighting the city's connection to the Byzantine Empire and its Christian heritage. 

In summary, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant representation of Thessaloniki's early Christian art and culture, reinforcing the city's connection to the Byzantine Empire and its Christian heritage. The mural serves as a reminder of the importance of preserving and celebrating Thessaloniki's cultural and historical heritage.

Sections of the city’s west walls

Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. response:
Christian murals are a significant aspect of Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments, particularly in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum. The church, built in 1310-1314, features early-Christian and Byzantine murals that date back to the 8th-11th centuries. These murals are a must-see, especially the ones on the dome depicting the Ascension of Christ, and the ones on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin's life. The church's south side also houses the church of Agios Ioannis Prodromos, built in 1940, and the early-Christian baptistery of Agia Sofia, built on the ruins of Roman baths.

The Roman Forum, located in the heart of the city, features several Christian murals, including the famous Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, also known as Metamorfosi Sotiros. This church, constructed around 1340, is a typical example of the transitional type in Byzantine church-building, found particularly in Macedonia. The church's architecture and murals showcase the city's rich cultural heritage and its blend of Roman, Byzantine, and Christian influences.

The significance of Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments lies in their representation of the city's Christian history and its role in the Byzantine Empire. These murals provide a glimpse into the city's past, showcasing the evolution of Christian art and architecture over the centuries. They also highlight the city's importance as a major center of Christianity, with the Apostle Paul being one of the first towns to know the Christian religion.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can explore these Christian murals and monuments, gaining a deeper understanding of the city's cultural and historical significance. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum are must-visit attractions, offering a unique glimpse into the city's rich heritage and its blend of cultures.
reference: Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments are significant as they reflect the city's early adoption of Christianity and its rich religious heritage. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos, showcasing the church's dedication to the Mother of God and its role in the Byzantine religious landscape. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as a social and religious center, contains an early Christian mural that highlights the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region. Together, these murals exemplify the artistic and spiritual evolution during the Byzantine period, contributing to Thessaloniki's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it showcases the early Christian period in Thessaloniki. The Roman Forum, a site of ancient ruins, houses a 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon, a mint, and an archive office. The mural, discovered during excavations, provides insight into the Christianization of the area during the Roman period. This mural is part of the broader context of Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which includes the UNESCO-listed Byzantine monuments. The Byzantine monuments, such as the Church of Agios Ioannis Prodromos and the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, date back to the 5th-15th centuries and are renowned for their impressive mosaics and murals. The early Christian mural in the Roman Forum is a unique example of the early Christian period in Thessaloniki, offering a glimpse into the city's rich Christian history. By studying this mural, one can appreciate the evolution of Christianity in the city and its connection to the broader Byzantine cultural heritage. The significance of this mural lies in its ability to provide a tangible link between the early Christian period and the Byzantine era, highlighting the city's complex and fascinating history. As a solo traveler in Thessaloniki, exploring these Christian monuments and the Roman Forum would be an excellent way to gain a deeper understanding of the city's cultural significance and significance. The early Christian mural in the Roman Forum is a must-see for anyone interested in history, art, and culture.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the transition of the city into a center of Christian faith during the Roman period. This mural, uncovered in a public storehouse, showcases the artistic expression of early Christianity. It relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which were constructed during the Byzantine period and reflect the city's historical importance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul. Both the mural and the monuments highlight Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the spread of Christianity in the Byzantine world.

user_input: What significance do the Christian murals found in Thessaloniki's Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum hold in relation to the city's early Christian heritage?

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '60

Sections of the city’s west walls  
remain along Arkadioupoleos and 
Eirinis Streets and finds related 
to Litaia Gate have recently 
been located at the corner 
of Agiou Dimitriou and Agiou 
Nestoros Streets. This gate 
used to be one of the seven 
great gates of the fortified city 
and formed part of the Early 
Christian period walls; it was 
named after Liti, a Byzantine 
town to which the gate led. 
The Golden Gate was also 
located on the Egnatia  
Street level.
2.8  Pasha Hamam  
[Paşa Hamami] (Phoenix  
Bath house).
It was built during the 
1520s by Cezeri Kasim Paşa. 
Also known as Phoenix Bath 
house, this used to be the 
last ottoman bath house open 
in town, as it closed down in

at the corner of Kalvou and 
Pineiou Streets, near the west 
walls and the church of the

structure of the building was 
planned with great care.', 'MAP OF THESSALONIKI

The area began to grow in 
the late 19th century, after the

wall and the ensuing pulling 
down of large sections of the 
city’s west and east walls. 
The short distance to the 
harbour and the rail system 
construction were two decisive 
factors which led to large 
industrial unit installations  
in the area. In recent decades 
many of these buildings 
were changed into culture

20th c.), near the FIX factory,

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
The Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum are significant in relation to the city's early Christian heritage. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I in 1310-1314, features early-Christian and Byzantine monuments, including the famous murals on the dome depicting the Ascension of Christ. These murals showcase the unique artistic expression of the early Christian period and demonstrate the city's importance as a center of Christian worship.

The Roman Forum, located in the heart of the city, is another significant site that holds importance in Thessaloniki's early Christian heritage. The forum was once a bustling marketplace and center of commerce, but it also played a crucial role in the spread of Christianity. The site is dotted with ruins of ancient buildings, including temples, basilicas, and theaters, which were likely used for early Christian worship and community gatherings.

The significance of these sites lies in their role as testaments to Thessaloniki's early Christian past. The city was one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul, and during the Byzantine period, it was a major center of Christian worship and art. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum are a physical manifestation of this heritage, showcasing the city's rich cultural and spiritual history.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can experience the significance of these sites firsthand by exploring the church and the forum. The church's murals and the forum's ruins offer a glimpse into the city's early Christian past, and by visiting these sites, travelers can gain a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's cultural and historical significance. Whether you are a history buff, an art lover, or simply someone interested in exploring the city's unique heritage, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum are must-visit sites in Thessaloniki.
reference: The Christian murals found in Thessaloniki's Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which depict Theotokos and the Founder, highlight the church's role as a significant early Christian monument built during the Byzantine period. Similarly, the early Christian mural uncovered in the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city, reflects the city's rich Christian heritage and its importance in the spread of Christianity during the early centuries. Together, these murals exemplify Thessaloniki's historical significance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul.

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. response:
In Thessaloniki, Christian murals hold significant importance in the context of Byzantine monuments, particularly in relation to the Holy Twelve Apostles Church. These murals depict various Christian themes and are a testament to the city's rich Christian heritage. The church itself, built in 1310-1314 under Patriarch Nephon I, features an impressive collection of murals that showcase the city's early-Christian and Byzantine past.

The murals in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church are not only a source of artistic and cultural fascination but also provide valuable insights into the city's historical development. They demonstrate the blending of early-Christian and Byzantine styles, reflecting the city's strategic location at the crossroads of Eastern and Western cultures.

In contrast, the Roman Forum, while a significant historical site, does not feature Christian murals. Instead, it is characterized by ancient Roman ruins and structures, offering a glimpse into the city's ancient past. The Roman Forum's historical significance lies in its representation of the city's ancient Roman heritage, whereas the Christian murals in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church highlight the city's unique Byzantine and Christian legacy.

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, with its impressive collection of Christian murals, is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments. The church's murals not only provide a visual representation of the city's early-Christian and Byzantine past but also serve as a poignant reminder of the city's rich cultural heritage.

In summary, Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments, particularly in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, hold significant cultural and historical value, offering a unique glimpse into the city's early-Christian and Byzantine legacy. These murals are an absolute must-see for anyone visiting the city, providing a visual representation of Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage.
reference: Christian murals in Thessaloniki are significant as they reflect the city's rich Byzantine heritage and its early adoption of Christianity. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos, showcasing the church's dedication to the Mother of God and its role in the Byzantine religious landscape. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as a social and religious center, contains an early Christian mural that highlights the transition from paganism to Christianity in the city. Together, these murals exemplify the artistic and spiritual evolution during the Byzantine period, contributing to Thessaloniki's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

user_input: What early Christian murals can be found in Thessaloniki, and how do they relate to the city's Christian heritage?

['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '72
MUSEUMS
by tradesmen. Aspects of 
the Byzantine everyday life, 
art and culture are depicted, 
covering the times from 
the early Byzantine until 
the post Byzantine period. 
The exhibition is structured 
by dates, in the following 
thematic categories:
• Early Christian or Early 
Byzantine period (4th–7th c.).  
It includes the chapters: i. The 
Early Christian church (room 
1) where the general shape 
and the particular elements 
of churches of that period are 
described, ii) Early christian 
town and house (room 2), 
offering some insight into 
the public and private life of 
people in those times and iii) 
From the Elysian Fields to the 
Christian Paradise (room 3) 
dealing with the burial of the 
dead and the cemeteries of 
the early Christian period.
• Middle Byzantine 
period (8th – 12th c.).', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', '92
DAY EXCURSIONS
a neolithic settlement which 
is considered to have been 
the largest in the Hellenic 
area, a cemetery, two early-
Christian basilicas (4th and 
6th c.) and a 10th c. basilica 
with remarkable mosaics and 
murals.
How to get there.  
Dion is situated 87 km SW 
of Thessaloniki. Follow the 
national road to Athens and 
then the signs to Katerini and 
Dion. Alternatively, take the 
coach to Katerini (Pieria district) 
and then the local bus to Dion.
4 	PETRALONA CAVE
It was discovered in 1959, 
by accident, in the western 
part of Halkidiki. It is 1,500 
m. long (a 400 m. section is 
open to visitors); the chambers, 
the stalagtite and stalagmite 
formations within are very 
interesting. The location 
became universally known 
when an array of prehistoric 
items was found in the interior 
(fossil tree leaves, bones of 
rhinos, elephants, equids, 
hyaenas etc), as well as 
vestiges of human activity such 
as traces of fire, stone tools 
and so on. However, the most 
important find is the skull of a 
woman who is approximately 
200,000-400,000 years old 
and is classed as a type in 
between Homo Erectus and 
Homo Sapiens, according 
to palaeoanthopologist A. 
Poulianos.', 'Other exhibits of great 
interest are the Hellenistic 
Bathhouse, the ancient brothel, 
and the fountain associated 
with the Stoa of the Statuettes 
(Las Incantadas). There are 
also finds related to the period 
from the Turkish Occupation 
until the 1917 fire. Next to 
exhibited items, there are 
descriptive texts and photos.
MUSEUM OF BYZANTINE 
CULTURE
It is considered one of the 
best museums in Greece and 
ranks high among its peers 
across the globe, offering 
a detailed picture of the 
Byzantine culture. Among 
the 2,900 masterpieces of 
exhibits, there are murals, 
mosaics, icons, marble 
architectural members, whole 
Early Christian tombs, church 
vessels, items of personal 
dress, as well as objects of 
everyday use and tools used

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
Thessaloniki is home to several early Christian murals that showcase the city's rich Christian heritage. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Baptistry of Agios Ioannis Prodromos are two notable examples. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church features a 14th-century mural depicting the Virgin Mary and the Apostles, while the Baptistry of Agios Ioannis Prodromos contains early Christian murals from the 5th century. These murals demonstrate the city's significant role in the early Christian period and its connection to the Byzantine Empire.

The early Christian murals in Thessaloniki are a testament to the city's importance as a major center of Christianity during the Byzantine period. The murals not only provide insight into the city's cultural and artistic heritage but also highlight the significance of Thessaloniki as a crossroads between the East and West. The city's early Christian churches, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Baptistry of Agios Ioannis Prodromos, were crucial in spreading Christianity throughout the region.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can experience the city's early Christian murals by exploring these churches and the surrounding areas. The murals are a must-see for anyone interested in history, art, and culture. By visiting these sites, travelers can gain a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's Christian heritage and its significance in the Byzantine Empire.

In addition to the murals, Thessaloniki is home to numerous other historical and cultural attractions, including the Byzantine Museum and the Museum of Byzantine Culture. These museums offer a wealth of information about the city's Byzantine past and its cultural significance.

Overall, the early Christian murals in Thessaloniki are an essential part of the city's cultural and historical landscape. They provide a glimpse into the city's rich Christian heritage and its connection to the Byzantine Empire. By exploring these murals and the surrounding attractions, travelers can gain a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's significance in the Byzantine period.
reference: In Thessaloniki, early Christian murals can be found in significant monuments such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which features a mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, reflecting the city's deep Christian heritage established by the Apostle Paul. Additionally, the Roman Forum contains a valuable early Christian mural uncovered in the double underground Cryptoporticus, showcasing the city's role as a social and religious center during the Roman period. These murals highlight Thessaloniki's historical significance as a hub of Christian art and architecture.

['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '72
MUSEUMS
by tradesmen. Aspects of 
the Byzantine everyday life, 
art and culture are depicted, 
covering the times from 
the early Byzantine until 
the post Byzantine period. 
The exhibition is structured 
by dates, in the following 
thematic categories:
• Early Christian or Early 
Byzantine period (4th–7th c.).  
It includes the chapters: i. The 
Early Christian church (room 
1) where the general shape 
and the particular elements 
of churches of that period are 
described, ii) Early christian 
town and house (room 2), 
offering some insight into 
the public and private life of 
people in those times and iii) 
From the Elysian Fields to the 
Christian Paradise (room 3) 
dealing with the burial of the 
dead and the cemeteries of 
the early Christian period.
• Middle Byzantine 
period (8th – 12th c.).', 'Other exhibits of great 
interest are the Hellenistic 
Bathhouse, the ancient brothel, 
and the fountain associated 
with the Stoa of the Statuettes 
(Las Incantadas). There are 
also finds related to the period 
from the Turkish Occupation 
until the 1917 fire. Next to 
exhibited items, there are 
descriptive texts and photos.
MUSEUM OF BYZANTINE 
CULTURE
It is considered one of the 
best museums in Greece and 
ranks high among its peers 
across the globe, offering 
a detailed picture of the 
Byzantine culture. Among 
the 2,900 masterpieces of 
exhibits, there are murals, 
mosaics, icons, marble 
architectural members, whole 
Early Christian tombs, church 
vessels, items of personal 
dress, as well as objects of 
everyday use and tools used 
MUSEUMS
80
81', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', '45
5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
Gialourou and Erasmou Streets. 
Eptapyrgio was built in the 12th 
c., presumably on an older 9th c. 
fortress and took this name as 
at first there were seven towers 
there. The current structure 
includes ten towers and a small 
street that goes around it. The 
north side used to be a part  
of the city’s Early Christian 
walls, whereas the towers  
on the south side were added 
during the Byzantine period. In 
1431, the Ottoman Turks made 
certain modifications to them, 
according to an inscription 
placed above the entrance. 
Circa 1890 the construction 
was changed in order to house  
long-term convicts and newer 
buildings were added on 
the inside as well as on the 
outside area. In 1989, the 
prison, known by its Turkish 
name – Yedi Kule, was housed 
elsewhere and the fortress 
became a monument open to 
visitors. It is well worth crossing 
the ring dirt road of the fortress 
where an early Christian cistern 
remains as well as parts of  
an early Christian basilica -  
the spot affords a lovely view!
11 	PALAIOLOGINA’S GATE
To reach Trigoniou Tower, you 
will go past the picturesque 
Agioi Anargyroi square, under  
a blanket of plane trees, where 
you will see Agioi Anargyroi 
church and small, traditional 
caffés and restaurants.']

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. response:
The Christian murals in Thessaloniki hold immense significance in relation to the city's early Christian history and its Byzantine monuments. These murals, found in various churches and monuments throughout the city, are a testament to the early Christian period and its influence on the Byzantine world.

During the early Christian period, Thessaloniki was one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul. As a result, numerous Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, showcasing the city's unique Christian heritage. The murals in these churches, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the St. John the Forerunner Church, depict various aspects of early Christian life, including the burial of the dead, the Elysian Fields, and the Christian Paradise.

These murals are also significant because they demonstrate the Byzantine period's influence on the city's early Christian history. During this time, the Byzantine Empire built upon the existing Christian structures, incorporating elements of Byzantine architecture and art. The murals found in Thessaloniki's churches and monuments, such as the murals on the dome of the Ascension of Christ Church, showcase the blending of early Christian and Byzantine styles.

In 1988, UNESCO declared Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments, including the Christian murals, to be World Heritage Sites. This recognition highlights the city's rich cultural heritage and its importance in the Byzantine world. Today, visitors can experience these murals firsthand by exploring the city's museums and churches, which offer a unique glimpse into Thessaloniki's early Christian history and its Byzantine monuments.

Overall, the Christian murals in Thessaloniki are a remarkable aspect of the city's cultural heritage, offering a fascinating glimpse into its early Christian history and its Byzantine monuments. Visitors to the city can experience these murals by visiting the various churches and monuments, which showcase the city's unique cultural identity.
